column1: A recent resume update led to significant changes in my job application results.   Initially, using an older layout, I faced multiple rejections and no callbacks. However, after revamping the layout, I secured two calls the day after applying and noticed increased recruiter interest on LinkedIn.  Here are my key tips for resume success:  🤖 **𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗼𝘁:** Structure your resume with key information at the top, especially technical skills relevant to the job. This increases the chances of passing through ATS systems effectively.  💡 **𝗔𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀:** Tailor your resume to match the job requirements closely. Aim for a score of 90+ to enhance your chances.  💯 **𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗳𝘆 𝗮𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗰𝘀:** Avoid fancy designs and formatting. Opt for a clean layout with hyphens instead of bullet points for better ATS compatibility.  Ensuring your resume aligns with the job description and is ATS-friendly can significantly boost your application success rate.  My approach, guided by ChatGPT as an ATS scorer, involved iterative edits to achieve scores between 80-85, refining further for each specific job until hitting a 90+ score.  Let's get some wins! …more

As a recruiter, I view resumes fairly often 😋  Hehe, if I can, just a few tips and ideas for those on the employment search? (I am by no means a PRO, this purely my opinion from patterns I and my team see.)  And by all means, ignore everything I say... we enjoy a good laugh 😁😁   Honestly, I would like to spend more time talking with YOU rather than asking about all the gaps or confusion that comes from unfinished or empty resumes. (I hope this finds the right audience 😬!)  So...  1. INTRO - We love an intro! Every Indeed manufactured resume looks generic with the "will relocate anywhere" which, frankly, isn't true. Tell me about you and what your goal is in seeking a new position! This helps me get a head start when I get a blurb about what you want and where you are at in your search.  2. DATES - For the love of all things holy and good and... Clean up your dates, don't leave gaps, and explain temp, contract, or seasonal jobs. We automatically rule out poor job longevity so if you explain the reason behind short-term positions, boom!  3. CONTEXT - Give me context please! Who are you?! Whether you work at a Warehouse, in Construction, or got involved in Manufacturing... it seems that unless you are OCD, most of the time there is a LACK of information on what you actually did on your resume. Keep in mind- sometimes title doesn't match responsibilities. Add leadership skills and certificates to your timeline so we can really see what you have to offer!  4. ERRORS- *clears throat. We pay attention to spelling and grammar errors. I mean, we're here to help update all that for your future employer, but if you catch it, make the change! This includes resume gaps that we want to understand AND inconsistency in punctuation, font, and bullet points. Take a second to review before uploading.  5. SKILLS - Don't let a resume generator do all the work! I want to know what YOU specifically can do and that is not always given proper honor when you allow a hiring site to guess your skills based on your previous roles. Really think about what you have accrued besides the typical additions of "time management" and "customer service." We know you have more to offer!  Just a few thoughts! We would love to give you and your future employer the BEST CHANCE in connecting. …more

The design, layout, and content of your resume are essential for capturing the reader's attention in the first 20 to 30 seconds. It’s important to approach this task with a clear strategy, focusing on highlighting your skills and experience in a concise and engaging way. Here are a few tips to help you craft the perfect resume:  1. Highlight your accomplishments: If you cut costs, increased revenue, delivered projects ahead of time, or broke company records, your resume is the perfect place to highlight these achievements using numbers and percentages to demonstrate your impact. 2. Call out the value you would bring to the target company: Just like in sports, where the value of a new player is debated, your resume is the place to highlight the value you can bring to a potential employer, using the language that aligns with the job you're applying for. 3. Identify the ways you help solve the company’s challenges: Just like an infomercial highlights a product’s strengths to solve a problem, your resume should showcase your professional assets and demonstrate how you can address the challenges of the company you're applying to.  The right job for you is out there. We can help get you to it  Click the link below to check out our blog!    …more

Is your resume starting to resemble a novel? 📚 Let's trim that epic down to a compelling short story!  Here's how: 1. Prioritize the Last 10-15 Years: Focus on your most recent experience; hiring managers are more interested in what you've done lately. 2. Highlight Achievements, Not Just Duties: Showcase your impact with quantifiable results—think revenue growth, cost savings, or process improvements. 3. Remove Outdated Skills: If it's no longer relevant (e.g., obsolete software), leave it out. 4. Use a Hybrid Resume Format: A skills-focused format helps showcase expertise before listing work history. 5. Tailor for Each Job: Only include roles that are directly relevant. Remember, your resume should be a highlight reel, not a documentary. Keep it concise, relevant, and future-focused to show why you're the best fit for today's job market.  What's your biggest challenge in keeping your resume concise? Let's discuss in the comments!  …more

I hear so many engineers asking about ATS-friendly resumes, so I am going to break it down for you today!  Let's use these tips for writing an ATS-friendly resume:  ✅ Use standard headings: - Stick to common headings like “Work Experience,” “Education,” & "Skills.”  ✅ Keep formatting simple: - Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that could confuse ATS systems.  ✅ Incorporate keywords: - Strategically incorporate relevant keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements. - Try to match 70-80% of job description language  ✅ Use a professional & readable font: -  Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.  ✅ Tailor each resume: - Customize your resume for each job application to reflect the specific job requirements.  ✅ Quantify relevant experiences: - Highlight measurable achievements and impactful projects.  Critical resume mistakes to avoid:  ❌ Omit personal details: - Do not include details like age, marital status, or photographs.  ❌ Avoid complex designs: - Skip colourful, overly creative layouts that distract from the main content.  ❌ Exclude irrelevant experiences: - Focus only on relevant, recent experience to keep your resume concise.  ❌ Keep graduate resumes short: - For fresh graduates, limit your resume to one page.  Your resume is your first impression, make sure it is clear, optimized, and ATS-friendly to increase your chances of landing an interview.  ✅ Focus on readability, relevance, and measurable impact. ✅ Use relevant keywords from the job description. ✅ Keep formatting clean and simple (avoid graphics/tables). ✅ Tailor each resume for the role, one-size-fits-all won’t work. ✅ Want better results? Apply online AND network with hiring managers!  Finally, 👉 An ATS-friendly resume doesn’t just pass the ATS, it gets you noticed by recruiters! 👉 ATS is just a tool, it doesn’t make hiring decisions! 👉 ATS is not your enemy, it is a tool that helps recruiters. 👉 Stop fearing it and focus on what you can control 👉 Make your resume work for you!  DMfor any questions or mentoring support!    ______________________________________________________________________________ 🙋‍♀️I am, , I have guided over 100+ engineers! …more

Recently, I reviewed a resume so GOOD, it made me pause in the middle of my lunch & call the candidate to schedule an interview.  It wasn't just the layout or the fancy font that caught my eye; it was the clear, concise way the candidate's achievements and experiences were presented.  It was evident they had done their homework, tailoring their resume specifically for the role, making it impossible to ignore.  So, what's the recipe for a standout resume? 📄✨  1. 𝐂𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐬 𝐊𝐞𝐲: Don't send out a one-size-fits-all resume. Tailor it to the job you're applying for, highlighting the experience and skills that align with the job description.   2. 𝐂𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬: Keep it clear and to the point. Use bullet points to break down your achievements and make them easy to read.   3. 𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐒𝐩𝐞𝐚𝐤 𝐋𝐨𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐫: Quantify your achievements. Increased sales by 20%? Reduced project delivery times by 30%? These figures grab attention.   4. 𝐀𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐌𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐬: Choose a clean, professional template that makes your resume easy on the eyes. But remember, simplicity doesn't mean boring.   5. 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐨𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝, 𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐨𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐀𝐠𝐚𝐢𝐧: Typos and grammatical errors can be the kiss of death for your application. Double-check, then have someone else check too.  𝐀𝐧𝐝 𝐢𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮'𝐫𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐭, 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐟𝐚𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐜𝐞𝐬 𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞.  ✅ Its simple math, you need the job >> you got to demonstrate why you're the perfect fit for the role.  So, take that extra time to craft a resume that reflects the best version of you. It might just be the reason you land your dream job. 💼🌈  FollowFor More! …more

Earning the trust of hiring managers is a steep mountain to climb, yet one that holds the key to effective  hashtag #recruitment. As someone who's been in the thick of it for years, I've navigated this climb and gathered invaluable insights.   Today, I want to share these time-tested tips to help you win over even the toughest of hiring managers:  1. Cultivate a partner mindset 🤝: First things first, you're not just a recruiter, but a strategic partner. Think about it. It's not just about filling a role; it's about understanding the unique requirements of a position, recognizing the team dynamic, and finding a person who fits like a glove.  2. Keep communication clear and consistent 💬: You've heard it before, and I'll say it again. Communication is key. Consistently update your hiring manager about the progress you're making, potential hiccups in the pipeline, and candidate feedback. Trust me, they'll appreciate your transparency.  3. Demonstrate market knowledge 📑: Show them you know your stuff. Keep abreast of industry trends, shifts in the job market, and salary benchmarks. Knowledge is power, and in this case, it can be the bridge to trust.  4. Go beyond the resume 📃: When you're presenting a candidate, don't just forward a . Instead, present a comprehensive view of the candidate's skills, experience, and cultural fit. Highlight why you believe they're right for the job. It's all about the details.  Keep these nuggets in your arsenal, and you'll be a hiring manager's dream in no time!  …more

Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.   Forget the usual advice.  People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.  We all know that doesn't work.  If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:  1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!  Have 20 years of experience?  Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!  Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.  Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!  2. Apply to the same job 37 times!  They'll have to notice you eventually right?  Persistence? Yes.  Stalking? That's for you to decide.  3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!  Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.  It's great for the culture!  4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.  It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!  I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.  Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share?  Let me know in the comments!  Have a great Saturday everyone!  …more

🕒 How I Review 100 Resumes in Under an Hour  Ever felt buried under a mountain of resumes? It’s easy to get overwhelmed, but there’s a faster, smarter way to sift through the noise and find the top talent. Here’s how I break it down:  1️⃣ Prioritize must-have skills: Start with non-negotiables. If the role requires Python or AWS experience, filter for it upfront.  2️⃣ Scan for relevant projects: Look for real-world examples where candidates contributed to projects similar to what you need.  3️⃣ Check for career progression: Promotions, increased responsibility, and diverse roles show growth and initiative.  4️⃣ Use keyword searches: Boolean search is your friend! Combine terms like “DevOps AND CI/CD” to narrow the pool.  5️⃣ Pre-set scorecards: Create a scoring system to stay objective. Rate candidates based on skills, experience, and key achievements. No more gut-feeling decisions!  ⚡ Pro Tip: Batch your review time—30 focused minutes beats hours of multitasking any day.  Need a breakdown of any of these steps? Let me know!👇  …more

Freshers, let’s talk resumes! 📝 Your resume is your first chance to impress, so let’s make sure it stands out for all the right reasons.  Here are some classic mistakes to avoid:  ❌ Generic objective statements: Employers want to know what you bring to the table. Personalize it! ❌ Too much text: Keep it concise. Focus on key achievements, not every job detail. ❌ Unprofessional email address: Keep it professional—your email should scream "I'm serious!" ❌ Overloading with skills: Quality over quantity. Highlight the skills that matter for the job! ❌ Not tailoring your resume: One-size-fits-all doesn't work. Customize for each role!  Remember, the goal is to make it easy for the recruiter to see why you’re the perfect fit. 💡  What’s the worst resume mistake you’ve seen? Drop it in the comments below and let’s share some laughs (or cringe-worthy moments)! 😂👇  …more

“Why is there a gap in your resume?”   This is the most common interview question that you will encounter if you have a career gap.  But wait- don’t worry.  Here’s how you can answer this question 👇  (This is the exact template)  “I took some time off to [reason for gap, e.g., care for a family member, pursue further education, etc.]. During this period, I [mention any productive activities, e.g., took online courses, volunteered, worked on personal projects] which helped me develop [specific skills relevant to the job]. Now, I’m excited and fully committed to bringing my enhanced skills and experiences to this role.”  That’s all.  And do you want a HIGH PAYING JOB Offer Letter? Wrote a client's resume today. 📝  Most people overthink this step, but after writing thousands of resumes, I’ve learned a few counterintuitive truths.  Here are 3 quick contrarian resume writing tips:  1️⃣ Write less, not more. Hiring managers skim. The more you write, the less they retain. 2️⃣ You are less important than the company’s needs. Your resume isn’t about you—it’s about how you solve their problems. 3️⃣ Stop trying to make it look pretty. Fancy designs don’t get jobs. Clear, scannable formatting does. 🔥 Uncommon Advice: Why Removing Certain Skills Could Strengthen Your Resume  More isn’t always better - Especially when it comes to your resume. 📄  Listing too many skills can actually dilute your impact and make recruiters question your expertise. Instead of a long, generic list, focus on high-value, role-specific skills that truly set you apart.  ✅ Cut These Skills NOW: ❌ Outdated tech (Think: Windows XP, MS-DOS) ❌ Basic skills (Recruiters expect MS Office & email proficiency) ❌ Unrelated skills (Graphic design on a sales resume?) ❌ Soft skills as bullet points (Show, don’t tell - “Excellent communicator” means nothing without proof.)  🔎 Instead, highlight industry-relevant, results-driven skills that match job descriptions.  💬 What’s one skill you think is overrated on resumes? The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.  NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.  START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.  INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.  FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.  END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.  Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below! …more

✨📄 Resume Building 101: Stand Out in 20 Seconds 📄✨ Did you know that employers typically spend only 20 to 30 seconds looking at a resume? Make every second count with these top tips: 1. Choose the Right Format: Highlight your experiences, skills, and abilities in a format that suits you best. A reverse chronological order is often effective, listing your most recent activities first. 2. Keep It Concise: Aim for a one-page resume with consistent formatting. Use bullet points and simple sentences for clarity. 3. Be Honest: Always be truthful. Employers verify information, and honesty is key. 4. Visual Appeal: Make your resume visually appealing to grab attention. 5. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight relevant skills and experiences. 6. Clear Objective: Include a clear resume objective to give employers insight into your interests. 7. Action Verbs: Start sentences with powerful action verbs to make your points impactful. 8. Error-Free: Ensure your resume is free of grammatical, spelling, punctuation, and typographical errors. 9. The Truth Behind 6 Resume Myths 🔊   There’s a lot of resume “wisdom” floating around the internet—but not all of it is accurate. Let’s bust six of the most common resume myths and set the record straight:  1. Your Resume Must Be One Page Not true! If you have substantial experience, it’s okay to go up to two pages. What matters is how relevant and concise your content is.  2. Gaps in Your Resume Are Dealbreakers Life happens! As long as you address gaps confidently and show how you stayed active or grew during them, it won’t sink your chances.  3. You Always Need References Nope! Employers typically ask for references after you’ve made it through the initial stages. Keep them on hand but off your resume.  4. Your Resume Should Be "Unique" A flashy, one-of-a-kind resume isn’t necessary unless you’re in a creative field. Focus on clarity and relevance instead of gimmicks.  5. You Have to List Your Full Address The days of snail mail are over! Just list your city and state—no need for your full address.  6. Dates and Employer Names Aren’t Important Think again! Hiring managers want to know where you worked and for how long. Dates and employer names give your experience credibility. …more

👀 Is Your Resume Easy to Read?  After you’ve created your resume, take a moment to visually inspect it. Why? Because if it’s hard to read or navigate, it might not get the attention it deserves. Here’s a quick checklist to ensure it stands out: 🔍 Top-to-Bottom Flow Does your resume naturally guide the reader’s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? That’s the most critical part—if it’s hard to find, you’re doing yourself a disservice.  📂 Key Details at a Glance Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.  🎯 Communicating Accomplishments Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments you’d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.  💡 Pro Tip If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. Research About the Company o Understand the company’s mission and values. o Familiarize yourself with their products/services. 2.   Update Resume o Tailor your resume for each job application. o Add any new skills or experiences. 3.   Align Skills with Job Roles o Highlight skills that match the job description. o Use examples that demonstrate those skills. 4.   Read Job Description Well o Identify key responsibilities and requirements. o  Ensure your resume addresses these points. Your resume gets 6 seconds.   SIX SECONDS. That’s all recruiters need...  To decide if your CV lands in the “no thanks” pile.  If your resume is sending the wrong signals, it’s game over—before you’ve even started.  Here’s how to fix it fast:  1. "I Didn’t Read the Job Posting." 🔴 Red Flag: Clichés like “detail-oriented” or “team player.” 🟢 Fix It: Mirror the job description. Use keywords and highlight specific achievements.  2. "I’m Living in the Past." 🔴 Red Flag: Listing ancient or irrelevant experience. 🟢 Fix It: Focus on the last 10 years. Keep it lean & relevant.  3. "I’m Afraid of Technology." 🔴 Red Flag: No mention of tools or platforms. 🟢 Fix It: Add your tech stack—Excel, Salesforce, or certifications. Digital fluency is mandatory.  4. "I’m Hiding Something." 🔴 Red Flag: Unexplained employment gaps. 🟢 Fix It: Fill the gaps—showcase freelancing, volunteering, or upskilling. Control the narrative.  5. "I Don’t Sweat the Details." 🔴 Red Flag: Typos, inconsistent formatting, outdated info. 🟢 Fix It: Use Grammarly. Polished resumes show you care.  6. "I Have No Results to Show." 🔴 Red Flag: Vague phrases like “managed a team” or “responsible for projects.” 🟢 Fix It: Quantify everything: “Boosted sales by 25%” > “Managed a team.”  7. "I’m Just Sending This Everywhere." 🔴 Red Flag: Generic resumes sent to every job. 🟢 Fix It: Highlight wins that match the job description.  8. "I’m Desperate." 🔴 Red Flag: Applying for every job under the sun. 🟢 Fix It: Stay focused. Align your resume to roles that tell one clear story.  🔥 Your Resume = Your Pitch.  If it’s not selling your story, it’s time for a rewrite.  What is your resume really saying about you?  ♻️ Share this to help someone today! 🔔 And followfor more. …more

Another lesson learned from responses I've received to "no thank you" emails sent to applicants: I occasionally get responses from applicants pointing out how relevant their experience is--experience not apparent in their resume. Candidates, make it easy on both sides:  * Customize your resume for every job you apply for. * Look at the skills, responsibilities, and experience in the job posting and then make sure as many of those as possible are explicitly stated in your resume (within the bounds of truth, of course). * Use easy-to-skim bullets. Don't make a recruiter squint through long paragraphs trying to understand your value. * Don't assume that a recruiter understands what your previous roles have involved. If you're applying for a job that requires phone skills, for example, spell out in your resume how you've used phone skills in previous roles.  Doing the above helps a recruiter quickly see your relevance to their job and boosts your chances of getting an interview. A win for all!   …more

Most résumés are boring and forgettable.  Here’s how to make yours stand out.   Most people treat their résumé like a history book, listing every job they’ve had and every task they’ve done.   But hiring managers don’t need a timeline, they need a reason to say YES.  Here’s how to make your résumé stand out in a way most people overlook:  🔹 Write for the Future, Not the Past Your résumé should position you for the job you WANT, not just reflect what you’ve done. Tailor your skills and accomplishments to align with the next step in your career.  🔹 Your Job Title Isn’t Enough, Show the Impact Instead of “Managed training programs,” say “Designed and implemented training programs that increased employee productivity by 30%.” Numbers tell a story.  🔹 Your Summary Shouldn’t Be Boring Avoid clichés like “hardworking professional seeking opportunities.” Instead, answer: What makes you different? Why should they hire YOU?  🔹 Remove Fluff That Wastes Space Phrases like “responsible for” or “assisted with” weaken your impact. Get straight to the result. What did you do? What happened because of it?  🔹 Make It Easy to Skim Hiring managers scan résumés in seconds. Use bold headings, bullet points, and clear formatting so they can see your value fast.  Your résumé isn’t just a document, it’s your first impression.  Make them want to know more.  Does your résumé sell your value or just list your past?  …more

📝 When writing your resume, remember to go beyond mere job descriptions (i.e., what you did day-to-day) and focus on showcasing your accomplishments.  Specifically, think about how you've contributed to your organization's success by making or saving money, furthering its mission and vision, and supporting your colleagues in doing the same.  🚀 While you can allocate a couple of sentences to outline your job responsibilities, the real value lies in emphasizing your achievements through well-crafted bullets.  Remember, your resume is not just a list of tasks you performed in previous roles. It's an opportunity to demonstrate the impact you've had on your past employers and how you can bring value to your future ones.  💼 Highlight quantifiable results: Share how your efforts led to cost savings, revenue growth, or process improvements within your team or organization.  🎯 Showcase your alignment with the company's mission and vision: Illustrate how your work contributed to advancing the organization's overall goals and objectives.  🤝 Emphasize collaboration and support: Describe instances where you collaborated with colleagues to achieve shared objectives or helped others achieve their goals.  🔍 Tailor your resume for each application: Customize your bullet points to align with the specific job requirements and showcase skills and achievements most relevant to the role.  💡 Use action verbs and metrics: Employ strong action verbs to describe your accomplishments and quantify your contributions with specific numbers, percentages, or metrics.  📈 Prove your value with real-world examples: Paint a clear picture of your impact by providing concrete examples of successful projects, initiatives, or problem-solving scenarios.  A well-crafted resume not only grabs the attention of recruiters and hiring managers but also sets you apart from other candidates by highlighting your unique contributions. So, remember, it's not just about the roles you've held; it's about what you've achieved and how that will benefit your future employer. Make every word count!  …more

Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective  To Employers: When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks: - Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction. - Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory. - Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities. - Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.  Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pause—it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.  To Job Seekers: - Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills. - Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals. - Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy. - Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.  Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. The painful truth about ATS "hacks" that no one's talking about...  I see job seekers spending countless hours: ✔️ Cramming keywords ✔️ Using white text ✔️ Creating complex tables ✔️ Testing "perfect" formatting tricks  Here's the reality: Modern ATS systems are FAR more sophisticated than you think. Those outdated hacks from 2015? They might actually be hurting your chances.  Instead, focus on what truly matters:  Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time.  Use clean, standard formatting Simple beats clever. Period. Your beautifully formatted resume means nothing if it's unreadable to human eyes.  Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.  Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. It's to reach the hiring manager's desk with a resume that makes them want to meet you.  Pro tip: Want to test your resume? Send it to yourself as a plain text file. If it's readable there, most ATS systems will handle it just fine.  Want to check your resume's ATS score? Land Your Dream Job with These Essential Resume Tips  Your resume is the first impression you make on recruiters, it’s your ticket to standing out in a competitive job market. Crafting a standout resume takes effort, but with the right approach, you can make it unforgettable. Here are some top tips to ensure your resume gets noticed:  1️⃣ Tailor Your Resume to the Job 🎯 Why it matters: Generic resumes don’t impress. Customize your resume for each role by aligning it with the job description. Highlight the skills and experiences that are most relevant to the position.  2️⃣ Highlight Relevant Experience 💼 Why it matters: Recruiters focus on what’s applicable to the job. Showcase experiences that align with the role. For unrelated roles, reframe your experience to demonstrate transferable skills.  3️⃣ Keep It Short 📝 Why it matters: Less is more in resume writing. Aim for a one- or two-page resume. Focus on concise, impactful descriptions of your skills and achievements.  4️⃣ Use Action Verbs 💪 Why it matters: Dynamic language grabs attention. Begin bullet points with action verbs like "led," "improved," "created," or "streamlined." Action verbs also help you stand out to Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS).  5️⃣ Choose the Right Format 📂 Why it matters: Your format reflects your career goals. Pick a chronological format for steady work history. Opt for a functional or hybrid format if you’re changing careers or highlighting skills.  6️⃣ Add Numbers 🔢 Why it matters: Metrics make your accomplishments tangible. Quantify your achievements (e.g., "boosted sales by 30%" or "managed a $2M budget"). Numbers help recruiters understand your impact.  7️⃣ Use a Modern, ATS-Friendly Template 📄 Why it matters: An ATS-friendly design ensures your resume gets seen. Avoid graphics, images, or complicated tables. Stick to clean, simple layouts that ATS software can easily parse.  Pro Tip: A great resume is your gateway to landing interviews. Invest time to polish it and consider professional services if needed.  …more

I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:  Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.  Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?  Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.  Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.  Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work – even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog 😊).  All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.  Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.  🏅 What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?   …more

🚀 Freshers, Ready to Land Your Dream Job? Here’s How! 🎯  Breaking into the job market as a fresher can feel overwhelming, but with the right preparation, you can stand out from the crowd and secure that offer! Prepare for Interviews Like a Pro Interviews are not just about answering questions—they’re about demonstrating confidence and problem-solving skills.  ✔ Know your resume inside out—expect questions on projects and internships. ✔ Practice common HR & technical interview questions. ✔ Be ready for behavioral questions like "Tell me about a time you faced a challenge." ✔ Mock interviews help—practice with friends or mentors.  💡 3. Develop Strong Communication & Soft Skills  Many companies look beyond technical skills!  🗣 Good communication helps you express ideas clearly.  🤝 Teamwork & adaptability show that you can fit into a company culture.  🧩 Problem-solving skills help you stand out in assessments & discussions.  🔗 4. Network & Use LinkedIn Effectively Your network can open doors to opportunities!  🌟 Connect with recruiters and professionals in your field.  💬 Engage with posts, share insights, and be active on LinkedIn.  📩 Don’t hesitate to message hiring managers—sometimes a simple DM can get you noticed.  🔥 5. Jeff Nevez, here with APC! I've seen countless resumes pass my desk. Unfortunately, some don’t make it to the next step for common, avoidable reasons. Here's what might be holding yours back:  🔑 Lack of Relevant Experience If your experience doesn't align with the job, recruiters may move on. Tailor your resume to highlight the most relevant skills and achievements.  📝 Poor Resume Formatting A cluttered or difficult-to-read resume can be a dealbreaker. Stick to a clean format with clear headings and bullet points.  📚 Missing Keywords Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) scan for specific keywords. If they’re missing, your resume may be filtered out before anyone sees it.  ⏳ Employment Gaps Without Explanation Gaps happen, and that’s okay—but explain them. Highlight growth during these periods, whether through learning, caregiving, or volunteering.  🎯 Generic Objective Statements Outdated or vague objectives don’t help. Use a strong professional summary to show your value upfront.  🔍 Typos and Grammar Errors Mistakes show a lack of attention to detail. Double-check or ask someone to review it for you.  ⚠️ Inconsistent or Inaccurate Information Inconsistent job titles or inflated claims raise red flags. Honesty is key.  📊 Lack of Measurable Achievements Just listing job duties isn’t enough. Show your impact using numbers, percentages, and results.  💡 By addressing these points, you’ll significantly increase your chances of getting noticed. Want more resume tips or career advice? I reviewed 4,000+ resumes last year. Here’s an anonymized Software Engineer resume. Let's roast it together ➡️   It’s a good resume, but small changes can double their chances of landing interviews.  Recruiters spend 6 (!) seconds per resume, so the first impression matters.   Some of the most common mistakes and what to do instead:  OVERDESIGNING  ❌ Using progress bars, decorative elements, overdesigning  ✅ Keeping design as simple as possible   DESIGNING FOR READING, NOT SCANNING  ❌ Long paragraphs, less bulleted lists  ✅ Bulleted lists, using the bold or italic font to highlight some experiences   SHORT EXPERIENCE DESCRIPTIONS  ❌ Focusing too much on education, certifications, etc.  ✅ Experience description should take up to 70-80% of the resume   NO COMPANY DESCRIPTIONS  ❌ Listing company names without context.  ✅ Adding 1-sentence company/product descriptions.   RESPONSIBILITIES OVER ACHIEVEMENTS  ❌ "Managed projects and oversaw deadlines."  ✅ "Led 3+ cross-functional teams, delivering 7 projects on time with a 98% client satisfaction rate.”   IRRELEVANT INFO  ❌ Adding technologies you are not using anymore.  ✅ Adding information relevant to the role you’re applying for   Comment “template” - and I’ll send you this EDITABLE FIGMA TEMPLATE. Use These copy-and-paste AI Prompts to Craft a Standout Cover Letter 👇  Make a lasting impression. Get more interviews. Land your dream role!  Try these 7 prompts to supercharge your cover letter:  ✉️ Prompt 1: Personalized Opening Creator Draft an engaging introduction tailored to [Company Name]. Highlight recent initiatives, values, or achievements. Create three variations: one focused on cultural alignment, one on innovation, and one on solving key challenges. Include "connection strength" and "engagement rating" for each. Limit to 75 words. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Company insights: [Paste Research].  ✉️ Prompt 2: Qualification Alignment Mapper Analyze [Job Title] requirements and match them to my qualifications in a table format with columns for 'Requirement', 'My Experience', and 'Proof of Success'. Add match strength percentages and key talking points. Identify three standout factors that differentiate me. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 3: Success Story Crafter Generate three impactful success stories tailored to [Target Role] using the Challenge-Action-Result framework. Focus on measurable outcomes and business impact. Rate each story's strength and memorability. Keep each story concise (50 words max). My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 4: Experience-Needs Connector Create a table linking [Job Title] priorities with my skills and accomplishments. Use columns for 'Company Need', 'My Contribution', and 'Supporting Evidence'. Assign relevance and impact scores for each entry. Limit entries to 15 words each. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 5: Culture Fit Demonstrator Identify core values and cultural traits from [Company Name]. Write evidence-based statements showing alignment with their mission and ethos. Present in a table with 'Company Value', 'My Experience', and 'Specific Example'. Include authenticity ratings for each match. Company insights: [Paste Research]. My resume: [Paste Resume].  ✉️ Prompt 6: Distinct Value Communicator Write a compelling second paragraph showcasing my unique strengths for [Role]. Develop three versions emphasizing problem-solving, innovation, or team-building skills. Include measurable results and forward-looking statements. Rate differentiation level for each version. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 7: Passion Statement Builder Craft an enthusiastic third paragraph expressing excitement about the opportunity at [Company Name]. Incorporate industry knowledge and company-specific insights. Create tailored versions for startups, corporate environments, or growth-stage businesses. Evaluate sincerity signals for each version. 3 Tricks to Make Your Résumé Stand Out  Recruiters receive hundreds of résumés daily, and the competition is fierce. If you want to catch their attention and land that interview, here are three simple but powerful tricks to make your résumé stand out:  1️⃣ Tailor Your Résumé to Each Job A generic résumé won’t do you any favours. Study the job description and highlight relevant skills, experience, and keywords. Show the recruiter that you’re the perfect fit for that specific role.  2️⃣ Make It Easy to Read Recruiters spend an average of 6–10 seconds scanning a résumé before deciding if they’ll read further. Use clear headings, bullet points, and a clean layout. Keep it concise—ideally one to two pages.  3️⃣ Show, Don’t Just Tell Instead of listing responsibilities, highlight your achievements. Use numbers to showcase your impact. For example, "Increased sales by 30% in six months" sounds stronger than "Responsible for sales growth." I bet most job seekers have fallen for these 5 resume myths at some point.    ------------------------------------   Let's clear the fog! 🎯  🚫 Myth 1: Resumes Should ONLY be One Page  Nope! Freshers, keep it short. But for experienced folks, focus on relevance. Feature what matters to the recruiter, even if it goes beyond one page.  🚫 Myth 2: Your Resume Should Be All Pretty and Flashy  Totally wrong! Your resume isn't an art project. Keep it clean and pro. Make the format easy on the eyes, not an eye-catcher.  🚫 Myth 3: Your Resume Should Have a Photo of You  False alarm! Unless they ask, skip the photo. It's a distraction, not a necessity. Save that space for something valuable.  🚫 Myth 4: Only Paid Experience Counts  Not true! If you're a fresher with internships and projects, they matter. No need for paid gigs right away. Your skills and efforts count too.  🚫 Myth 5: You Need to Add an Objective Section  Nah, they're kinda useless. Everyone wants to apply their skills. Instead, use that space wisely. Highlight your key skills and results – make it count.   -----------------------------------------   Remember, stay informed and keep your knowledge fresh. 👀 Is Your Resume Easy to Read?  After you’ve created your resume, take a moment to visually inspect it. Why? Because if it’s hard to read or navigate, it might not get the attention it deserves. Here’s a quick checklist to ensure it stands out: 🔍 Top-to-Bottom Flow Does your resume naturally guide the reader’s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? That’s the most critical part—if it’s hard to find, you’re doing yourself a disservice.  📂 Key Details at a Glance Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.  🎯 Communicating Accomplishments Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments you’d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.  💡 Pro Tip If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. Tip of the Week: Your Resume Should Be a Movie Trailer, Not the Whole Script  If your resume reads like a generic job description, we have a problem. Hiring managers don’t want to see a list of what you were supposed to do—they want to see what you actually did.  Saying “Managed cloud infrastructure” is the resume equivalent of saying you “existed” at work. Instead, try “Optimized cloud resources to cut hosting costs by 35% while improving system uptime to 99.98%.”  See the difference? Numbers, results, and real impact make you stand out.  Think of your resume like a movie trailer—it should hook the audience, highlight the best moments, and leave them wanting more. What projects did you crush? What problems did you solve? How did your work make life easier, faster, or more efficient for your team? If your resume doesn’t make hiring managers excited to learn more, it’s time for a rewrite.  Hiring managers want problem-solvers, not a recap of job duties. Show them the action, the impact, and the results.  What’s the best resume tip that helped you land an interview? “Productive Perspective” #11  ❌Common Resume Mistakes That Can Get You Rejected Instantly!  As a reviewing countless resumes daily, I still see candidates making these avoidable mistakes. Here are some key reasons why resumes get rejected at first glance:  1. Grammatical & Spelling Errors – A resume full of typos reflects a lack of attention to detail. Proofread carefully or use tools like Grammarly.  2. Listing Every Possible Tool & Technology – Don’t just add all buzzwords to get a call. Only mention technologies you have actual hands-on experience with.  3. Over-Reliance on AI-Generated Resumes – Using AI (like ChatGPT) to refine your resume is fine, but copying generic content can make it sound impersonal and irrelevant to your real experience.  4. Frequent Job Hopping Without Explanation – If your resume shows job changes every few months or years, it raises red flags for recruiters. Address it in your profile summary if needed.  5. Vague One-Word Responsibilities – Writing generic words like “Implementation,” “Development,” or “Support” for every project doesn’t help. Be specific about your contributions.  6. Missing Project Durations & Education Year – Always mention the timeline for each project and your education year to avoid confusion about experience level.  Want to stand out? Avoid these mistakes and craft a resume that truly reflects your skills and experience!  🤔Did i miss on something? 🗣️Share your views..  …more

With over 250 applications per job opening on average, that resume needs a strategic approach to consistently grab the attention needed to get you in the door.  So, is yours designed for easy consumption and comprehension? If you are only paying attention to what goes in it and not how it is delivered, you might have a problem.  Hiring managers and recruiters spend hours reviewing resumes, their eyes weary and strained. Respect their time by ensuring your resume is easy to read and navigate.  Here are some best practices for making your resume as readable as possible:  📜 Use a Clean Design: Stick to professional fonts (like Arial, Calibri, or Times New Roman) and avoid unnecessary graphics or images. Keep font sizes between 10 and 12 points for readability.  📜 Structure for Navigation: Use clear headings, bold job titles, and bullet points to guide the reader through your experience. Think of your resume as if it were a map. Navigation cues will help your reader find the information they need quickly.  📜 Emphasize White Space: White space isn’t wasted space, it is in fact essential for readability. Like a well-designed advertisement, a resume with balanced white space draws attention to key points and prevents the page from feeling overwhelming. Research done in the graphic design field emphasizes that white space enhances readability and legibility, allowing key information to stand out and reducing cognitive load for the reader.  📜 Tailor and Highlight: Place the most relevant achievements and skills at the top of each section. You only have seconds to make an impression, so make those seconds count.  Make no mistake, folks. That resume is supposed to be a marketing tool and not just some laundry list of duties. The design and layout needs to reflect that. Just as advertisers use clean layouts to convey a message quickly, your resume’s design should allow hiring managers to see your value at a glance.  What’s one thing you could do today to make your resume more readable?  …more

Get Your Resume Noticed  8 Key Scannable Points (and What Recruiters REALLY Want to See ) hashtag hashtag    Crafting a resume that gets past the initial screening can feel like cracking a code! Here are the top 8 things recruiters typically scan for (forget page count!):  Location: Make it easy for them to see if you're a local candidate.   Summary/Profile: Briefly showcase your key experiences and what makes you stand out.   Company Name (1-3 sentence summary): Quickly explain what the company did (e.g., "Developed educational software for children" or "Managed social media campaigns for a non-profit").   Title: Highlight the specific role you held (use the same wording as the job description if possible).   Dates: Be transparent about your employment history, including month and year (short stints are okay!).   Metrics: Quantify your achievements whenever possible (e.g., "Increased website traffic by 20%"). Numbers grab attention!   Education: Include it if it's relevant to the job (essential for some roles like doctors or engineers).   Technical Skills (if applicable): List relevant skills, but showcase them further in your bullet points with specific examples.   What else are recruiters looking for?  While "soft skills" aren't the answer this time, here are some recruiter favorites: Clear and concise writing (avoid typos!) ️  Strong action verbs that showcase your achievements (e.g., "spearheaded," "managed," "increased")  Tailored content that speaks directly to the job description   P.S. Big Company Work Experience? Be Specific!  If you worked for a giant like Google, mention the specific division or function (e.g., "Google Search Ads team" or "Google Cloud Platform engineering"). This clarifies your unique experience within the vast company.   By focusing on these key elements, you can craft a resume that gets noticed and lands you that interview! …more

Would you like different results in your career?  Then you’ll have to do things differently!  Career growth and job searching can feel like a game, and to win, you need to know the rules.  But if you want extraordinary results—ones that most people never achieve—you need to play differently.  Doing what everyone else is doing will lead to the same rejections and frustrations. It's time to change your approach.  -For starters, don’t just send resumes. Build connections!  Reach out to people at the companies you're interested in and have conversations—people hire people, not resumes or job boards.  -Next, tailor your resume for each application.  Use tools to identify relevant keywords and align your experience with the role. It’s a small effort that can make a huge difference.  -Showcasing your work is another powerful strategy.  Share your achievements on platforms like LinkedIn or create a portfolio to highlight your skills and projects. A simple resume doesn’t fully show your capabilities. Take it a step further to stand out and leave a lasting impression.  -Networking is crucial—but don’t wait until you need help.  Build genuine relationships consistently so that when the time comes, you have a strong network to lean on.  -And don’t be afraid to take risks.  Experiment with new skills, tackle unfamiliar problems, and step out of your comfort zone. Growth happens when you challenge yourself.  -Lastly, lift others as you climb.  You don’t need a title to make an impact. Mentor, support, and share knowledge with others. Helping people along the way often leads to unexpected opportunities.  To achieve different results, you need to take a different path. Start implementing these strategies today and see the difference they can make. 🚀 5 Common Writing Mistakes (And How to Fix Them!) ✍️  Great content isn’t just about writing—it’s about writing well. Yet, many writers (even experienced ones) fall into these common traps: ❌ 1. Fluffy Introductions 👉 Mistake: Taking too long to get to the point. ✅ Fix: Hook your reader in the first sentence! Start with a bold statement, a stat, or a question. ❌ 2. Overusing Jargon 👉 Mistake: Using complex terms that confuse readers. ✅ Fix: Write like you're explaining to a 10-year-old. Keep it clear and concise. ❌ 3. Writing Without Structure 👉 Mistake: Huge blocks of text that scare readers away. ✅ Fix: Use headings, bullet points, and short paragraphs to improve readability. ❌ 4. Forgetting SEO 👉 Mistake: Writing great content but ignoring keywords. ✅ Fix: Research and naturally integrate relevant keywords to improve rankings. ❌ 5. Weak Call to Action (CTA) 👉 Mistake: Leaving readers without a next step. ✅ Fix: End with a clear CTA—whether it’s subscribing, sharing, or commenting. 🚀 Pro Tip: Writing is a skill that improves with practice. Keep refining, keep learning! 👉 What’s one writing mistake you’ve learned to avoid? Drop it in the comments! ⬇️    …more

🚀 Want to stand out in the competitive job market? Here are the top 3 things you can do to make your resume shine! ✨  1. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight the skills and experiences most relevant to the role you're applying for. Your IT/tech job descriptions might be turning candidates away. 🛑  This is how to fix them! ✅  ➡️ 1. Start with a clear job title Avoid jargon or creative titles that confuse candidates. A straightforward job title like "Software Engineer" performs better in search results and aligns with candidate expectations.  ➡️ 2. Include a strong opening summary Summarize the role in 2-3 sentences. Focus on the core purpose of the job and how it contributes to the company’s goals, keeping it concise and engaging.  ➡️ 3. Outline key responsibilities clearly List the main tasks in bullet points. Be specific to avoid ambiguity—avoid general phrases like "handle IT projects" and specify the exact responsibilities.  ➡️ 4. Focus on day-to-day activities Paint a picture of a typical day in the role. This helps candidates visualize the job and assess if it's the right fit for them.  ➡️ 5. Specify required skills and technologies Clearly list must-have technical skills, such as Python, SQL, or AWS. This filters candidates early and saves time for both parties.  ➡️ 6. Differentiate between ‘required’ and ‘preferred’ skills Clearly label "must-have" versus "nice-to-have" skills. This helps attract qualified applicants while keeping the door open for those who may have potential.  ➡️ 7. Set realistic expectations for experience levels Be precise about the experience level required—whether it's entry-level or senior. Avoid broad terms like "junior" or "experienced" without clear year-based guidelines.  ➡️ 8. Explain the purpose of the role Describe why the role exists and how it fits into the company's broader goals. This provides context and meaning, motivating the right candidates to apply.  ➡️ 9. Highlight career growth opportunities Mention internal development programs or career paths. Candidates want to know how they can progress within your company, especially in a fast-paced industry like IT.  ➡️ 10. Provide a clear reporting structure State who the candidate will report to. This helps candidates understand where the role fits in the organizational hierarchy and clarifies team dynamics.  ... and 14 further must-read tips in the carousel below!  …more

Did you recently get passed over for a role you thought you were a perfect fit for? Job hunting can be a challenging journey, and rejection, while tough, is often part of the process. Instead of letting frustration take over, take a step back and assess your approach. Are there areas where you could refine your strategy? Below are a few insights that might help you turn things around and boost your chances for success.  1. Are You Aiming Too High? One common mistake candidates make is applying for roles that may be slightly out of reach. It’s natural to want to push for the next level in your career, but are your qualifications truly aligned with the position you’re applying for?  If you find yourself consistently passed over for roles that require more experience or a broader skill set, it might be time to reassess and realign. Consider seeking a company with a clear advancement policy or a position that will help bridge the gap between where you are now and where you want to go. Remember: career growth is a marathon, not a sprint.  2. Have You Updated and Tailored Your Resume? Your resume is the first impression you make on potential employers. Have you taken the time to thoroughly update it before submitting your applications? A rushed, generic resume could be the reason you’re not getting callbacks.  Think carefully about the content you’re showcasing. Are you just listing broad job duties, or are you clearly communicating your achievements and the value you've added in your previous roles? Employers want to see specific examples of how you’ve contributed to the success of your past organizations. Instead of simply stating “responsible for managing a team,” try adding more depth: “Led a team of 8 to successfully implement a project that resulted in a 15% increase in operational efficiency.”  Refine each bullet point, focusing on accomplishments and measurable outcomes that highlight your unique value.  3. Are You Preparing for Interviews? Winging it simply won’t cut it. The competition is fierce, and preparation is key. If you’re not taking the time to prepare for interviews, you’re missing out on one of your best chances to shine.  Think about your most significant career achievements—those moments that truly made an impact at your previous companies. Be ready to share specific metrics, numbers, and examples that demonstrate your value.  It’s also important to keep your answers concise. Hiring managers often have limited time, so make sure you’re answering questions thoroughly without going off on tangents. Practice telling your stories in a clear, impactful way that highlights your expertise while remaining focused on the relevant details.  4. Bonus: Explore Interview Tips from Experts If you’re feeling stuck or unsure about how to best prepare for interviews, consider checking out resources like Janet Jones’ profile for a series of valuable tips on acing interviews. …more

Your resume gets 6 seconds.   SIX SECONDS. That’s all recruiters need...  To decide if your CV lands in the “no thanks” pile.  If your resume is sending the wrong signals, it’s game over—before you’ve even started.  Here’s how to fix it fast:  1. "I Didn’t Read the Job Posting." 🔴 Red Flag: Clichés like “detail-oriented” or “team player.” 🟢 Fix It: Mirror the job description. Use keywords and highlight specific achievements.  2. "I’m Living in the Past." 🔴 Red Flag: Listing ancient or irrelevant experience. 🟢 Fix It: Focus on the last 10 years. Keep it lean & relevant.  3. "I’m Afraid of Technology." 🔴 Red Flag: No mention of tools or platforms. 🟢 Fix It: Add your tech stack—Excel, Salesforce, or certifications. Digital fluency is mandatory.  4. "I’m Hiding Something." 🔴 Red Flag: Unexplained employment gaps. 🟢 Fix It: Fill the gaps—showcase freelancing, volunteering, or upskilling. Control the narrative.  5. "I Don’t Sweat the Details." 🔴 Red Flag: Typos, inconsistent formatting, outdated info. 🟢 Fix It: Use Grammarly. Polished resumes show you care.  6. "I Have No Results to Show." 🔴 Red Flag: Vague phrases like “managed a team” or “responsible for projects.” 🟢 Fix It: Quantify everything: “Boosted sales by 25%” > “Managed a team.”  7. "I’m Just Sending This Everywhere." 🔴 Red Flag: Generic resumes sent to every job. 🟢 Fix It: Highlight wins that match the job description.  8. "I’m Desperate." 🔴 Red Flag: Applying for every job under the sun. 🟢 Fix It: Stay focused. Align your resume to roles that tell one clear story.  🔥 Your Resume = Your Pitch.  If it’s not selling your story, it’s time for a rewrite.  What is your resume really saying about you?  ♻️ Share this to help someone today! 🔔 And followfor more. …more

Here are my top tips to make your resume stand out!! The goal is clarity and readability. A well-organised, professional resume creates a positive first impression and helps employers quickly see why you're a strong candidate.  Over the next few weeks, I'll also provide tips on what to avoid including in your resume and seek your input on some debatable topics you might believe should be included.  START WITH THE BASICS - Create a clear, professional header with your name, in a larger font, (your header is the first thing employers will notice) and include in a smaller font your phone number and email for easy readability.  SUMMARY - Include a brief summary under your header highlighting your skills, experience, and career goals to showcase and make a strong first impression that you’re the right fit for the job.  SKILLS - Highlight relevant expertise here, tailoring them to the job description and including transferable skills.  HIGHLIGHT YOUR ACHIEVEMENTS AND EDUCATION- List your degrees, certifications, courses, languages, awards, key achievements, professional memberships, accreditations, and volunteer work.  SOFTWARE – List all software programs you’ve used in a separate section under your achievements.  CAREER SUMMARY TABLE – Provide a VERY BRIEF snapshot of your past roles under your listed software, including job title, company, and dates worked. Start with your most recent roles, and include your expanded detailed tasks separately on the following pages.  EMPLOYMENT HISTORY ⦿ Include company name, job title, promotions, exact dates, and if a permanent or a contract role. ⦿ Keep your resume concise - 1-3 pages max, or up to 4 if you have over 20 years of experience. List the last 15 years of experience in reverse order, condensing older roles past 15 years unless they are relevant to the job. ⦿ Dot point tasks - Write in first person without "I," e.g., “Scheduled and organised client appointments.” ⦿ Make it precise and measurable - saying “increased sales by 20%” is more impactful than “improved sales”, instead of “updating clients,” say “updated 60 clients weekly.” ⦿ Include specific skills and highlight keywords from the job description in your resume to showcase your relevant experience. ⦿ Briefly explain employment gaps, whether due to travel, study, COVID, redundancy, family, or other reasons.  FORMATTING - Use a consistent 10-12 pt font, bold headers only, bullet points for tasks, and a professional font like Times New Roman or Arial. If using lines, keep them thin and light-coloured.  PROOFREAD – Print or read your resume aloud to spot errors, and have a detail-oriented friend review it.  FINISHING TOUCHES - Name it properly, using your name followed by "Resume” and save your resume as a PDF to maintain its format.  "MOST IMPORTANTLY", BE HONEST - Honesty is key to your resume. Dishonesty can harm your chances and reputation. Stay truthful! …more

In today’s competitive job market, your resume is often your first impression with potential employers—and it needs to shine. But what if writing isn’t your strength? That’s where hiring a professional resume writer can be a game-changer. However, not all resume writers are created equal, and investing in the wrong one could leave you frustrated or, worse, still unemployed.  Before you commit, here are three essential questions to ask to ensure you’re making the right choice:  1. What is their experience and expertise? Not every resume writer understands your specific field or career goals. Ask about their professional background and how long they’ve been writing resumes. Look for someone who understands your industry and has a proven track record of success. Bonus points if they’ve worked in recruiting or HR—they’ll have insider knowledge of what hiring managers are looking for.  2. How do they tailor resumes to individual clients? Avoid writers who rely on generic templates or canned phrases. A great resume writer will ask in-depth questions about your experience, achievements, and career goals. Their goal should be to tell your unique story while ensuring your resume passes applicant tracking systems (ATS). Be wary of anyone who promises a one-size-fits-all approach.  3. Can they provide examples, reviews, or testimonials? Reputable resume writers will gladly share client testimonials or samples of their work. Seeing evidence of their ability to produce results can give you peace of mind. If they’re unwilling to provide this, it might be a red flag. ________________________________  A resume is an investment in your career, and choosing the right professional can make all the difference. Asking these questions ensures that you’re selecting someone who understands your needs and can deliver real value.  Want even more tips on hiring the best resume writer? I reviewed 4,000+ resumes last year. Here’s an anonymized Software Engineer resume. Let's roast it together ➡️   It’s a good resume, but small changes can double their chances of landing interviews. Some of the most common mistakes and what to do instead:  OVERDESIGNING  ❌ Using progress bars, decorative elements, overdesigning  ✅ Keeping design as simple as possible   DESIGNING FOR READING, NOT SCANNING  ❌ Long paragraphs, less bulleted lists  ✅ Bulleted lists, using the bold or italic font to highlight some experiences   SHORT EXPERIENCE DESCRIPTIONS  ❌ Focusing too much on education, certifications, etc.  ✅ Experience description should take up to 70-80% of the resume   NO COMPANY DESCRIPTIONS  ❌ Listing company names without context.  ✅ Adding 1-sentence company/product descriptions.   RESPONSIBILITIES OVER ACHIEVEMENTS  ❌ "Managed projects and oversaw deadlines."  ✅ "Led 3+ cross-functional teams, delivering 7 projects on time with a 98% client satisfaction rate.”   IRRELEVANT INFO  ❌ Adding technologies you are not using anymore.  ✅ Adding information relevant to the role you’re applying for   Comment “template” - and I’ll send you this EDITABLE FIGMA TEMPLATE. "You’re Not Getting Hired Because You’re Forgetting This ONE Thing"  Most job seekers are stuck in a never-ending loop: Apply. Wait. Hope. Repeat.  And when they don’t get hired, they blame the economy, the job market, or even bad luck. But here’s the truth: It’s not the market. It’s your strategy. Here’s what top recruiters won’t tell you: Your resume isn’t just a piece of paper—it’s your business card for a six-figure opportunity. Yet, most job seekers treat it like a last-minute college essay. Think about this: Would Apple sell an iPhone in a plain cardboard box? Would Nike slap a logo on a plain sneaker and hope for the best? No. They tell a story. They highlight the value. They sell the vision. Now, let me ask you this: Does your resume sell YOU as the premium, top-tier professional you are? Or is it just a list of tasks you did 3 years ago? Because here’s the thing: recruiters don’t read resumes, they SKIM. And if you can’t grab their attention in 6 seconds, you’re already in the “no” pile. Here’s what to do instead: Tell a story: Don’t just list responsibilities—show results. Instead of “Managed a team,” write, “Led a team of 10 to increase productivity by 25% in 6 months.” Make it skimmable: Use bullet points, bold key achievements, and highlight metrics. Position yourself as the solution: Every job listing is a problem. Your resume should scream, “I’m the answer!”  Stop thinking like an applicant and start thinking like a business. Because here’s the hard truth: There is no success with “almost.” Either you’re the obvious choice—or you’re invisible.  If you’ve been struggling to land interviews, it’s not the job—it’s the approach. Fix that, and watch doors open.  What’s stopping you from leveling up your resume today? Let’s talk!  …more

✨📄 Resume Building 101: Stand Out in 20 Seconds 📄✨ Did you know that employers typically spend only 20 to 30 seconds looking at a resume? Make every second count with these top tips: 1. Choose the Right Format: Highlight your experiences, skills, and abilities in a format that suits you best. A reverse chronological order is often effective, listing your most recent activities first. 2. Keep It Concise: Aim for a one-page resume with consistent formatting. Use bullet points and simple sentences for clarity. 3. Be Honest: Always be truthful. Employers verify information, and honesty is key. 4. Visual Appeal: Make your resume visually appealing to grab attention. 5. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight relevant skills and experiences. 6. Clear Objective: Include a clear resume objective to give employers insight into your interests. 7. Action Verbs: Start sentences with powerful action verbs to make your points impactful. 8. Error-Free: Ensure your resume is free of grammatical, spelling, punctuation, and typographical errors. 9. Use Keywords: Incorporate industry-specific keywords and phrases to make your resume relevant to recruiters. For example, if you're an Accounting major, include 'CPA Eligible by May 2025'. 10. Show Leadership and Achievements: Highlight any leadership roles, achievements, and organizational involvement. Make sure these are also visible on your LinkedIn profile. Remember, a well-crafted resume can make a significant difference in your job application process. Let's make your resume shine! 🌟  …more

Here are some common resume pitfalls transitioning military job seekers fall into:  🚩 1. The ‘One-Size-Fits-All’ Resume  Using the same generic resume for every job application is a surefire way to get ignored.  Solution: Tailor your resume to each job by aligning your skills and experience with the job description.  🚩 2. No Metrics, No Proof  Saying you "improved processes" in the military is vague. Saying you "increased efficiency by 30% and reduced costs by $50K" is impactful.  Solution: Use quantifiable achievements to show your value.  🚩 3. The Job Description Copy-Paste Trap  Regurgitating your job duties from a military or corporate role isn't compelling.  Solution: Translate responsibilities into accomplishments. Hiring managers want to know how you made an impact, not just what you were assigned to do. Make sure to use action verbs, metrics, and show results.  🚩 4. Too Much Military/Career Jargon  Don't use military jargon and acronyms that civilians don't understand. If your resume reads like a mission report, it won’t resonate with civilian recruiters.  Solution: Simplify terminology and explain how your skills transfer to the industry you’re targeting.  🚩 5. Keyword Deficiency  Many resumes get rejected by recruiters because you are not proving how you meet the skills nor address the key words listed in the job description.  Solution: Don't just list all of your previous job responsibilities, use relevant industry keywords and skills from the job description, and SHOW how you've done THAT thing they want you to know how to do.  A resume isn’t just a piece of paper; it’s your personal marketing document.  Avoid these mistakes, and you’ll get closer to landing an interview.  Maloney out! ✌     …more

I hear so many engineers asking about ATS-friendly resumes, so I am going to break it down for you today!  Let's use these tips for writing an ATS-friendly resume:  ✅ Use standard headings: - Stick to common headings like “Work Experience,” “Education,” & "Skills.”  ✅ Keep formatting simple: - Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that could confuse ATS systems.  ✅ Incorporate keywords: - Strategically incorporate relevant keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements. - Try to match 70-80% of job description language  ✅ Use a professional & readable font: -  Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.  ✅ Tailor each resume: - Customize your resume for each job application to reflect the specific job requirements.  ✅ Quantify relevant experiences: - Highlight measurable achievements and impactful projects.  Critical resume mistakes to avoid:  ❌ Omit personal details: - Do not include details like age, marital status, or photographs.  ❌ Avoid complex designs: - Skip colourful, overly creative layouts that distract from the main content.  ❌ Exclude irrelevant experiences: - Focus only on relevant, recent experience to keep your resume concise.  ❌ Keep graduate resumes short: - For fresh graduates, limit your resume to one page.  Your resume is your first impression, make sure it is clear, optimized, and ATS-friendly to increase your chances of landing an interview.  ✅ Focus on readability, relevance, and measurable impact. ✅ Use relevant keywords from the job description. ✅ Keep formatting clean and simple (avoid graphics/tables). ✅ Tailor each resume for the role, one-size-fits-all won’t work. ✅ Want better results? Apply online AND network with hiring managers!  Finally, 👉 An ATS-friendly resume doesn’t just pass the ATS, it gets you noticed by recruiters! 👉 ATS is just a tool, it doesn’t make hiring decisions! 👉 ATS is not your enemy, it is a tool that helps recruiters. 👉 Stop fearing it and focus on what you can control 👉 Make your resume work for you! 🚨 Let’s talk about AI and resumes! The Truth Behind 6 Resume Myths 🔊   There’s a lot of resume “wisdom” floating around the internet—but not all of it is accurate. Let’s bust six of the most common resume myths and set the record straight:  1. Your Resume Must Be One Page Not true! If you have substantial experience, it’s okay to go up to two pages. What matters is how relevant and concise your content is.  2. Gaps in Your Resume Are Dealbreakers Life happens! As long as you address gaps confidently and show how you stayed active or grew during them, it won’t sink your chances.  3. You Always Need References Nope! Employers typically ask for references after you’ve made it through the initial stages. Keep them on hand but off your resume.  4. Your Resume Should Be "Unique" A flashy, one-of-a-kind resume isn’t necessary unless you’re in a creative field. Focus on clarity and relevance instead of gimmicks.  5. You Have to List Your Full Address The days of snail mail are over! Just list your city and state—no need for your full address.  6. Dates and Employer Names Aren’t Important Think again! Hiring managers want to know where you worked and for how long. Dates and employer names give your experience credibility. …more

When I started looking for a job, people said I should apply to a lot of them. But it didn't work out that way. I applied to many jobs and often got no response.  Why? Because when we rush, we sometimes miss important details about what the job needs. It's like trying to hit a target without looking.  Instead of applying to tons of jobs randomly, it's better to focus on a few. Take time to understand what the job is about and what the company wants. Then, change your resume to match that. Make it fit what the company is looking for.  It's not about sending out a bunch of resumes—it's about sending the right ones. Quality is more important than quantity. If you match your resume with the job, you're more likely to get a call.  So, don't worry about applying everywhere. It's not a race. Take your time, understand the job, and then make your move. It's about being smart, not just being fast.  …more

📄 Resume Tips from a Recruiter (Take Them or Leave Them - could be my opinions only, so I welcome any other recruiters to chime in!)  I’ve been deep in resume reviews over the past few weeks, and a few things have stood out. So, in the spirit of kindness and humor, here are some unsolicited tips to (hopefully) help you stand out in the best way possible:  🎨 Go easy on the colors. A small splash of color? Cool. A rainbow? Distracting. Subtle and professional is the way to go. 📜 Get to the good stuff quickly. I promise, most recruiters don’t spend much time on those paragraphs or “highlight” sections at the top. Put your experience front and center—I want to see what you’ve done without scrolling through a novel first. ⚠️ Meet the minimum requirements (and be honest). If the role requires X, Y, and Z, please have X, Y, and Z. And lying on preliminary questions? Just don’t. It’s awkward for everyone. 📊 Skip the charts, graphs, and graphics. They look fancy, but honestly, I usually scroll right past them. They don’t always add the value you think they do. ✂️ Less is more. A focused, impactful resume beats one crammed with every single task you’ve ever done. Prioritize metrics and achievements—they’re your best friends. 📸 No pictures, please. That space is better used for you—your experience, skills, and what makes you a great candidate. 💡 I know the job market is tough right now, and it can be hard to know what works. I hope these tips are helpful as you polish up your resume. And know this: I’m rooting for you all! Good luck out there—you’ve got this! 💪 …more
