CV/Resume Building: Your First Step to Career Success   Your CV is often the first impression you make with a potential employer. Yet, many job seekers find themselves struggling with screening tests and not getting the calls they hope for. Instead of spending big on CV-building services, I believe the real investment is in time—and leveraging accessible tools like Canva, Adobe, or even simple MS Word. Here are a few key tips to help you boost your CV’s chances of passing those screening hurdles:  1. Keep it Precise - Especially for freshers, it’s tempting to include everything. But remember, less is more. Seek advice from professionals in your field or a consultant to streamline your content and keep it relevant.  2. Leverage AI Tools - Don’t miss out on the power of design! Use AI platforms to give your CV a polished, modern look. Plenty of templates are available, and a well-designed CV stands out.  3. Formatting Matters - Ensure your CV is easy to read. Poor formatting—like mismatched fonts, inconsistent alignments, and heavy borders—can overwhelm the reader. Keep it clean and simple.  4. Spell Check, Always - A CV with spelling or grammatical errors sends the wrong message. Always double-check and, if possible, ask someone else to review it too.  5. Highlight Relevant Interests & Achievements - Tailor your CV to the role you're applying for. Sure, your singing talent is great, but if you’re applying for a finance role, highlighting your interest in business, finance, or the stock market will capture the recruiter’s attention.  || Brownie Tip ||  Use an ATS-Friendly Format - Here's a tip most people don't know—make sure your CV is ATS-friendly (Applicant Tracking System). Many companies use ATS to filter CVs before they even reach a hiring manager. Stick to standard fonts, avoid images or complex formatting, and use keywords from the job description to increase your chances of passing the automated screening.  Remember, a well-crafted CV isn’t just a list of qualifications—it’s your story in a nutshell. Spend the time to make it shine, and you’ll find yourself one step closer to that dream job. ✨ Use Your Words Wisely – Especially on Your Resume! ✨ Have you ever been told to use your words wisely? This advice doesn’t just apply to conversations—it’s crucial when crafting your resume. When I come across a resume packed with words, no matter how well-written, it often misses the mark. Why? It doesn’t tell your story. A resume like that could belong to anyone. To make your resume uniquely yours, focus on these key elements: 🔹 Scope: Describe your role—what was the scale of your responsibilities? What volume or team size did you manage? 🔹 Success: Highlight your achievements. What results did you deliver? What makes you stand out? 🔹 Recognition: Were you the “Manager of the Year”? The go-to person for a major initiative? Share it! Quantify your accomplishments with numbers, symbols, KPIs, and specifics to show your impact. Once you master this, you’ll never view resumes the same way again. Let’s compare two examples: 1️⃣ Strategic leader, hands-on with the team, developing client-centric initiatives to deliver an exceptional client experience. 2️⃣ Strategic leader, motivating teams to deliver exceptional service, resulting in a 14% sales increase YOY and growing appointment business from 8% to 17% of total sales. The second example tells a story. It’s clear, measurable, and impactful—and it speaks volumes about the candidate's contributions. 💡 Remember: Your resume should showcase your unique journey, not just a generic job description. What are your tips for crafting a standout resume? Share below—I’d love to hear your thoughts! …more

There is one phrase you should NEVER say to someone who is unemployed due to a layoff or something outside of their control.  "Enjoy your time off!"  Ah yes....because losing your job is the all expenses paid vacation that NOBODY asked for.  Let's be real:  ❌ Bills don't take a vacation. Rent, groceries, and student loans didn’t seem to get the memo that you're “off work.”  ❌ Job searching is a full-time job. Updating resumes, networking, and applying to 10-15 jobs a day isn't sipping margaritas on the beach.  ❌ Stress levels are high when you are unemployed and "relaxing" is tough when you are wondering how long your savings account will last.  Instead of telling someone to "enjoy" their time off, try saying this instead:  ✅ "How can I support you?" ✅ "Who can I introduce you to in my network that can help?" ✅ "If you need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out."  Being unemployed is anything but a vacation.  These jobseekers didn't ask for this time off.  They want to get back to work.  Let's continue to support these jobseekers instead of giving them a "silver lining" speech.   ________________________________________________________________________________  Want more authentic job searching tips and career advice in your news feed? DEAR JOB SEEKERS  THIS IS WHAT INCREASES YOUR CV SCORE ON THE APPLICANT TRACKING SYSTEM (ATS)  1) SKILLS: You can either have skills in your career objective, job bullet points, separate section or you can have skills in all the above mentioned.  2) LINKEDIN URL: Adding a hyperlink to your Linkedin Profile will help you share information about yourself that might be too much for your CV.  3) CONTACT NUMBER AND E-MAIL ADDRESS Tip: Employers will use either of these two to communicate, make sure the email address spelling is correct and the numbers aren’t swapped around.  4) FILE NAME: Always use your First Name and Surname, using anything else might cause your CV to be discarded or marked off as suspicious.  5) FILE SIZE The file must be under 2 mb. If your CV is bigger than 2 mb you need to remove attachments (copies of qualifications, cover page pictures, photos) or simply re-save it in a different format that will allow for file compression.  6) FILE TYPE: The recommended file type to use is PDF (Not scanned), you must be able to highlight the text. Word can be used as well but PDF will cause the least problems.  7) DATE FORMATTING: Include the month and year for both the start and the end date, the most recent experience being at the top going down.  Have a productive day job seekers, you’re all winners for not giving up!  …more

Recruiters don’t read resumes—they scan them.  That means if yours doesn’t grab attention in seconds, it’s getting skipped.  So, what actually makes a recruiter stop and take a second look?  Here’s a breakdown of how they think:  1️⃣ The 6-Second Rule → Recruiters aren’t reading essays. They skim for key details.  2️⃣ Your Top Half Matters Most → Name, title, contact info, LinkedIn and a compelling professional summary should be on the top.  3️⃣ Strategic Keywords → Use industry-specific terms in your headline and summary. If they don’t see relevant skills fast, you’re out.  4️⃣ Showcase Your Expertise → Your headline should highlight what you bring to the table, not just your job title.  5️⃣ Clean, Readable Formatting → If your resume looks cluttered, it won’t get read. Stick to clear fonts, white space, and a structured layout.  Think of your resume as a first impression. If it doesn’t catch attention in 6 seconds, it’s time for a revamp. The secret to stress-free resume writing? Break it into these 3 steps.  One of the biggest mistakes professionals make when job hunting is trying to do everything at once when it comes to their resume—creating, curating, and tailoring all in one sitting.  The result? Frustration, burnout, and a resume that doesn’t do justice to your accomplishments.  Here’s how to simplify the process and build resumes that work—without wasting time or energy.  1️⃣ Create Your Master Resume Start with a "base resume"—a document that lists everything you’ve done. Jobs, projects, achievements, responsibilities—get it all down without worrying about formatting or structure. The goal? To create a comprehensive record of your career history.  2️⃣ Curate for Clarity Now, trim it down. Organize your experience by grouping similar accomplishments and focusing on the most relevant wins. Think about the roles you’re targeting—what will make you stand out to recruiters or hiring managers?  3️⃣ Craft for Each Role This is where you shine! Use your curated content to craft tailored resumes that match specific job descriptions. Highlight the top 10% of your experience that aligns 100% with the job. Tools like’s AI Resume Builder make this step faster and easier by helping you extract relevant keywords and score how well your resume matches the job.  Breaking down the resume-writing process not only saves you time but ensures you’re always putting your best foot forward.  What’s your biggest challenge when it comes to writing your resume? A well-crafted CV/Resume not only opens doors but also tells your unique career story. I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:  Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.  Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?  Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.  Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.  Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work – even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog 😊).  All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.  Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.  🏅 What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?   …more

The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.  NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.  START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.  INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.  FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.  END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.  Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below! …more

I reviewed 4,000+ resumes last year. Here’s an anonymized Software Engineer resume. Let's roast it together ➡️   It’s a good resume, but small changes can double their chances of landing interviews.  Recruiters spend 6 (!) seconds per resume, so the first impression matters.   Some of the most common mistakes and what to do instead:  OVERDESIGNING  ❌ Using progress bars, decorative elements, overdesigning  ✅ Keeping design as simple as possible   DESIGNING FOR READING, NOT SCANNING  ❌ Long paragraphs, less bulleted lists  ✅ Bulleted lists, using the bold or italic font to highlight some experiences   SHORT EXPERIENCE DESCRIPTIONS  ❌ Focusing too much on education, certifications, etc.  ✅ Experience description should take up to 70-80% of the resume   NO COMPANY DESCRIPTIONS  ❌ Listing company names without context.  ✅ Adding 1-sentence company/product descriptions.   RESPONSIBILITIES OVER ACHIEVEMENTS  ❌ "Managed projects and oversaw deadlines."  ✅ "Led 3+ cross-functional teams, delivering 7 projects on time with a 98% client satisfaction rate.”   IRRELEVANT INFO  ❌ Adding technologies you are not using anymore.  ✅ Adding information relevant to the role you’re applying for   Comment “template” - and I’ll send you this EDITABLE FIGMA TEMPLATE. Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.   Forget the usual advice.  People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.  We all know that doesn't work.  If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:  1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!  Have 20 years of experience?  Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!  Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.  Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!  2. Apply to the same job 37 times!  They'll have to notice you eventually right?  Persistence? Yes.  Stalking? That's for you to decide.  3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!  Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.  It's great for the culture!  4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.  It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep! Instead, focus on what truly matters:  Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time. Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.  Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. It's to reach the hiring manager's desk with a resume that makes them want to meet you.  Pro tip: Want to test your resume? Send it to yourself as a plain text file. I've seen tons of resumes. Here are some common pitfalls I've seen:  1️⃣ Overloading with Text: Keep it clean and concise. Highlight your top achievements instead of listing every responsibility individually.  2️⃣ Skipping Keywords: Tailor your resume to the job by using keywords from the posting. Yes, this is an extra step, but it's worth it.  3️⃣ Generic Summaries: Customize your summary to show how you bring unique value to the role that you're applying for.  4️⃣ Ignoring Metrics: Use numbers to show impact. For example: "Increased efficiency by 30%" is much stronger than "Improved processes."  5️⃣ Formats: Resumes should be sleek and ATS-friendly. Stick to a design that’s easy to read.  Follow, Connect or DM for more. 🚀  What are your biggest resume pet peeves? Drop them in the comments—I’d love to hear! 👇  …more

Think of it as your marketing pitch for why you are awesome for the position.  🎯Keep the formatting simple. No photos, emojis, graphs, charts, or references.  🎯 Most people (and 98% of my clients) have 2 page resumes. 🕒 How I Review 100 Resumes in Under an Hour  Ever felt buried under a mountain of resumes? It’s easy to get overwhelmed, but there’s a faster, smarter way to sift through the noise and find the top talent. Here’s how I break it down:  1️⃣ Prioritize must-have skills: Start with non-negotiables. If the role requires Python or AWS experience, filter for it upfront.  2️⃣ Scan for relevant projects: Look for real-world examples where candidates contributed to projects similar to what you need.  3️⃣ Check for career progression: Promotions, increased responsibility, and diverse roles show growth and initiative.  4️⃣ Use keyword searches: Boolean search is your friend! Combine terms like “DevOps AND CI/CD” to narrow the pool.  5️⃣ Pre-set scorecards: Create a scoring system to stay objective. Rate candidates based on skills, experience, and key achievements. No more gut-feeling decisions!  ⚡ Pro Tip: Batch your review time—30 focused minutes beats hours of multitasking any day.  Need a breakdown of any of these steps? Let me know!👇  …more

Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective  To Employers: When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks: - Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction. - Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory. - Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities. - Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.  Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pause—it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.  To Job Seekers: - Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills. - Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals. - Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy. - Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.  Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. 12 ways to email like a boss (even if you aren’t one)  Being too nice in emails weakens your message. It makes people brush off your requests.  ----  Here’s a tool to create a professional resume that stands out and passes ATS filters*: 👉🏻  ----  Here are 12 email responses to sound more confident:  Addressing a Delay ❌ "Sorry for the delay." ✅ "Thank you for your patience."  Acknowledging a Mistake ❌ "Sorry I missed that." ✅ "Thank you for bringing this to my attention."  Responding to Appreciation ❌ "No worries." ✅ "I’m always happy to assist."  Following Up on Progress ❌ "Just checking in." ✅ "When can I expect an update?"   Ensuring Clarity ❌ "Hopefully that makes sense?" ✅ "Please let me know if you have any questions."  Considering New Ideas ❌ "Maybe we can consider..." ✅ "Let's explore additional options."  Requesting Feedback ❌ "Let me know what you think." ✅ "I’d appreciate your feedback."  Asking for a Review ❌ "If it’s not too much trouble..." ✅ "Could you please take a look and advise?"   Setting Expectations ❌ "I’ll try to get it done by Friday." ✅ "I will have it done by Friday."  Clarifying a Point ❌ "I’m not sure, but..." ✅ "Based on my understanding..."  Addressing a Concern ❌ "I’m a little worried about that." ✅ "There are some concerns we should address."  Proposing a Meeting ❌ "Let me know when you’re free." ✅ "Would you be available to discuss this?"  The right words can change how others respond to you. Choose them wisely and see better results. A resume is a document that summarizes your skills, experience, and education. It is typically used to apply for jobs. Here are some tips on how to write a resume: * Choose a format. -‐----------------‐-‐------------- There are three main resume formats: chronological, functional, and combination. A chronological resume lists your work experience in reverse chronological order. A functional resume focuses on your skills and abilities. A combination resume combines elements of both chronological and functional resumes.  * Start with your contact information. --------------------------------------------------------------- This includes your name, address, phone number, and email address. * Write a resume objective or summary. A resume objective is a statement of your career goals. A resume summary is a brief overview of your skills and experience.  * List your work experience. ----------------‐------------------------------- For each job, include the company name, job title, dates of employment, and a brief description of your responsibilities.  * List your education. ------------------------------------- Include the name of the school, degree earned, and graduation date.  * List your skills. ------------------------------ This can include both hard skills (such as computer skills) and soft skills (such as communication skills).  * Proofread your resume carefully. ----------------‐----------------------------------------- Make sure there are no typos or grammatical errors.  * Tailor your resume to the specific job you are applying for. ------------------‐----------------------------------------------------- Highlight the skills and experience that are most relevant to the job. Here are some additional tips: * Use action verbs to describe your accomplishments. * Quantify your accomplishments whenever possible. * Keep your resume concise and easy to read. * Use a professional font and layout. -----------------------------------‐---------------------------------- …more

Use These copy-and-paste AI Prompts to Craft a Standout Cover Letter 👇  Make a lasting impression. Get more interviews. Land your dream role!  Try these 7 prompts to supercharge your cover letter:  ✉️ Prompt 1: Personalized Opening Creator Draft an engaging introduction tailored to [Company Name]. Highlight recent initiatives, values, or achievements. Create three variations: one focused on cultural alignment, one on innovation, and one on solving key challenges. Include "connection strength" and "engagement rating" for each. Limit to 75 words. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Company insights: [Paste Research].  ✉️ Prompt 2: Qualification Alignment Mapper Analyze [Job Title] requirements and match them to my qualifications in a table format with columns for 'Requirement', 'My Experience', and 'Proof of Success'. Add match strength percentages and key talking points. Identify three standout factors that differentiate me. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 3: Success Story Crafter Generate three impactful success stories tailored to [Target Role] using the Challenge-Action-Result framework. Focus on measurable outcomes and business impact. Rate each story's strength and memorability. Keep each story concise (50 words max). My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 4: Experience-Needs Connector Create a table linking [Job Title] priorities with my skills and accomplishments. Use columns for 'Company Need', 'My Contribution', and 'Supporting Evidence'. Assign relevance and impact scores for each entry. Limit entries to 15 words each. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 5: Culture Fit Demonstrator Identify core values and cultural traits from [Company Name]. Write evidence-based statements showing alignment with their mission and ethos. Present in a table with 'Company Value', 'My Experience', and 'Specific Example'. Include authenticity ratings for each match. Company insights: [Paste Research]. My resume: [Paste Resume].  ✉️ Prompt 6: Distinct Value Communicator Write a compelling second paragraph showcasing my unique strengths for [Role]. Develop three versions emphasizing problem-solving, innovation, or team-building skills. Include measurable results and forward-looking statements. Rate differentiation level for each version. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 7: Passion Statement Builder Craft an enthusiastic third paragraph expressing excitement about the opportunity at [Company Name]. Incorporate industry knowledge and company-specific insights. Create tailored versions for startups, corporate environments, or growth-stage businesses. Evaluate sincerity signals for each version. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Company insights: [Paste Research].  👉 Follow me for more AI-powered career tips!  🔄 Share this post to help others elevate their job applications! …more

🚀 Resume Tips to Stand Out! Your resume isn’t just a document—it’s your personal brand. Make it impactful with these key tips: 1️⃣ Show, Don’t Tell – Instead of claiming you're skilled, prove it through concrete achievements and real-world results. 2️⃣ Skip Overused Buzzwords – Hardworking and team player are filler words. Let your accomplishments speak for themselves. 3️⃣ Showcase Your Career Growth – Highlight promotions to demonstrate your progress and recognition in previous roles. 4️⃣ Put Your Best Work First – Arrange your resume so that your strongest projects and achievements are at the top. 5️⃣ Use Bold Text – Highlight the technologies you used and the impact of your work to make key details stand out. 6️⃣ Keep It Concise – Remove redundancy and keep your resume clear, structured, and to the point. 7️⃣ Maintain a Clean, Professional Look – Skip the photo and fancy designs. A simple black-and-white layout ensures readability and professionalism. 8️⃣ Be Specific, Not Generic – Phrases like "developed multiple APIs" or "fixed several bugs" lack impact. It seems like the purpose of a resume has shifted over the years. What used to be a representation of what I have done has now turned into a mirror of what a job posting says. Why is that?  Resumes are supposed to tell the story of my career — the skills I’ve developed, the challenges I’ve overcome, the value I bring to the table. Yet now, it feels like they are being molded to fit specific keywords and criteria, which often doesn't even capture the full picture of my expertise.  As someone who's looking to transition into a new career field, I’m also facing the challenge of how to reframe my experience. How do I showcase my marketable skills and transferable expertise, especially when my background doesn’t perfectly align with the job titles listed in the postings?  Shouldn’t our resumes reflect our unique capabilities and experiences, not just echo job descriptions? How do we balance staying true to our professional journeys while also satisfying algorithm-driven filters?  What do you think, and community? How do we reclaim the authenticity of our resumes while also ensuring they are seen — especially when making a career transition?  …more

The most common resume mistake I see when working with people:  Including a measurable result  ... that you literally can't measure.  ChatGPT does a great job pulling measurable results to put in your resume when you type in this prompt:  "What are some measurable accomplishments JOB POSITION can put in their resume?"  But it'll give you ideas that are clearly ChatGPT'd.  "Improved time from order to serving food by 25%"  Did you really time every order and calculate how much your "tailored customer service strategy reduced xyz"?  ...and was it really exactly a 25% increase?  Make sure you pick results that are measurable & more importantly TRUE  You can fully expect the interviewer to press you on "how exactly did you achieve this result?" Jeff Nevez, here with APC! I've seen countless resumes pass my desk. Unfortunately, some don’t make it to the next step for common, avoidable reasons. Here's what might be holding yours back:  🔑 Lack of Relevant Experience If your experience doesn't align with the job, recruiters may move on. Tailor your resume to highlight the most relevant skills and achievements.  📝 Poor Resume Formatting A cluttered or difficult-to-read resume can be a dealbreaker. Stick to a clean format with clear headings and bullet points.  📚 Missing Keywords Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) scan for specific keywords. If they’re missing, your resume may be filtered out before anyone sees it.  ⏳ Employment Gaps Without Explanation Gaps happen, and that’s okay—but explain them. Highlight growth during these periods, whether through learning, caregiving, or volunteering.  🎯 Generic Objective Statements Outdated or vague objectives don’t help. Use a strong professional summary to show your value upfront.  🔍 Typos and Grammar Errors Mistakes show a lack of attention to detail. Double-check or ask someone to review it for you.  ⚠️ Inconsistent or Inaccurate Information Inconsistent job titles or inflated claims raise red flags. Honesty is key.  📊 Lack of Measurable Achievements Just listing job duties isn’t enough. Show your impact using numbers, percentages, and results.  💡 By addressing these points, you’ll significantly increase your chances of getting noticed. Want more resume tips or career advice? 💡 Tips for Crafting a Winning Resume! 🚀  Your resume is your personal marketing tool. It needs to capture attention and showcase your skills and experience in the best light possible. Here are some essential tips to make your resume stand out:  1. Clear Contact Information Make sure your name, phone number, email address, and LinkedIn profile are easy to find. If you have a personal website or portfolio, include that too!  2. Compelling Professional Summary Kick things off with a brief but powerful summary of your experience, strengths, and career goals. This sets the tone for the rest of your resume.  3. Tailored Skills Section List relevant skills for the job you're applying for. Focus on a balance of both hard and soft skills that match the role.  4. Achievements Over Responsibilities Instead of just listing job duties, highlight your key achievements. Quantify your successes with numbers (e.g., increased sales by 30%, led a team of 5).  5. Experience That Shows Impact Describe your roles using action verbs and focus on the impact you made. This will demonstrate your contribution and value to potential employers.  6. Keep It Concise A resume should be no longer than 1-2 pages. Be concise and cut out unnecessary information. Employers often skim resumes, so make it easy for them to spot key details.  7. Education & Certifications List your degrees, certifications, and any additional training relevant to the job. Be sure to include dates and institutions.  8. Use Keywords Many companies use Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) to scan resumes. Include keywords from the job description to ensure your resume gets noticed.  9. Formatting Is Key Keep your resume clean, professional, and easy to read. Use bullet points, bold for headings, and leave enough white space to make it visually appealing.  10. Proofread, Proofread, Proofread! Typos can make a bad impression! Always proofread your resume (or ask a friend) to catch any errors.  Remember, your resume is often the first impression a recruiter or hiring manager gets of you, make it count! 🌟    …more

Your resume gets 6 seconds.   SIX SECONDS. That’s all recruiters need...  To decide if your CV lands in the “no thanks” pile.  If your resume is sending the wrong signals, it’s game over—before you’ve even started.  Here’s how to fix it fast:  1. "I Didn’t Read the Job Posting." 🔴 Red Flag: Clichés like “detail-oriented” or “team player.” 🟢 Fix It: Mirror the job description. Use keywords and highlight specific achievements.  2. "I’m Living in the Past." 🔴 Red Flag: Listing ancient or irrelevant experience. 🟢 Fix It: Focus on the last 10 years. Keep it lean & relevant.  3. "I’m Afraid of Technology." 🔴 Red Flag: No mention of tools or platforms. 🟢 Fix It: Add your tech stack—Excel, Salesforce, or certifications. Digital fluency is mandatory.  4. "I’m Hiding Something." 🔴 Red Flag: Unexplained employment gaps. 🟢 Fix It: Fill the gaps—showcase freelancing, volunteering, or upskilling. Control the narrative.  5. "I Don’t Sweat the Details." 🔴 Red Flag: Typos, inconsistent formatting, outdated info. 🟢 Fix It: Use Grammarly. Polished resumes show you care.  6. "I Have No Results to Show." 🔴 Red Flag: Vague phrases like “managed a team” or “responsible for projects.” 🟢 Fix It: Quantify everything: “Boosted sales by 25%” > “Managed a team.”  7. "I’m Just Sending This Everywhere." 🔴 Red Flag: Generic resumes sent to every job. 🟢 Fix It: Highlight wins that match the job description.  8. "I’m Desperate." 🔴 Red Flag: Applying for every job under the sun. 🟢 Fix It: Stay focused. Align your resume to roles that tell one clear story.  🔥 Your Resume = Your Pitch.  If it’s not selling your story, it’s time for a rewrite.  What is your resume really saying about you?  ♻️ Share this to help someone today! 🔔 And followfor more. …more

Most résumés are boring and forgettable.  Here’s how to make yours stand out.   Most people treat their résumé like a history book, listing every job they’ve had and every task they’ve done.   But hiring managers don’t need a timeline, they need a reason to say YES.  Here’s how to make your résumé stand out in a way most people overlook:  🔹 Write for the Future, Not the Past Your résumé should position you for the job you WANT, not just reflect what you’ve done. Tailor your skills and accomplishments to align with the next step in your career.  🔹 Your Job Title Isn’t Enough, Show the Impact Instead of “Managed training programs,” say “Designed and implemented training programs that increased employee productivity by 30%.” Numbers tell a story.  🔹 Your Summary Shouldn’t Be Boring Avoid clichés like “hardworking professional seeking opportunities.” Instead, answer: What makes you different? Why should they hire YOU?  🔹 Remove Fluff That Wastes Space Phrases like “responsible for” or “assisted with” weaken your impact. Get straight to the result. What did you do? What happened because of it?  🔹 Make It Easy to Skim Hiring managers scan résumés in seconds. Use bold headings, bullet points, and clear formatting so they can see your value fast.  Your résumé isn’t just a document, it’s your first impression.  Make them want to know more.  Does your résumé sell your value or just list your past?  …more

👀 Is Your Resume Easy to Read?  After you’ve created your resume, take a moment to visually inspect it. Why? Because if it’s hard to read or navigate, it might not get the attention it deserves. Here’s a quick checklist to ensure it stands out: 🔍 Top-to-Bottom Flow Does your resume naturally guide the reader’s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? That’s the most critical part—if it’s hard to find, you’re doing yourself a disservice.  📂 Key Details at a Glance Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.  🎯 Communicating Accomplishments Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments you’d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.  💡 Pro Tip If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. Top 5 resume tips that get you interviews:  1. Lead with the section of your resume with the most value.  Example: if you don't have any experience but have a Masters in Business Analytics, start your resume with your education section.  2. Show specific, numeric impact.  Example: Increased gross revenue by 3% as measure by...  ❌ don't use generic or fake percentages like 20% or 50%. If you cant measure impact, don't use a percentage.  3. Only include skills that you can validate.  Example: If you include Machine Learning in your skills section, you better have some machine learning project or experience in your resume.  4. Add the title you want to be on your resume.  Example: if you have done data analytics at a previous job, but you worked in operations, ask your previous manager if you can change the job title to data analyst on your linkedin and resume.  5. Use 𝗯𝗼𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 strategically.  ❌ don't bold skills ✅ bold your impact or outcome of a project  what important resume tips am I missing?  …more

As a recruiter, I view resumes fairly often 😋  Hehe, if I can, just a few tips and ideas for those on the employment search? (I am by no means a PRO, this purely my opinion from patterns I and my team see.)  And by all means, ignore everything I say... we enjoy a good laugh 😁😁   Honestly, I would like to spend more time talking with YOU rather than asking about all the gaps or confusion that comes from unfinished or empty resumes. (I hope this finds the right audience 😬!)  So...  1. INTRO - We love an intro! Every Indeed manufactured resume looks generic with the "will relocate anywhere" which, frankly, isn't true. Tell me about you and what your goal is in seeking a new position! This helps me get a head start when I get a blurb about what you want and where you are at in your search.  2. DATES - For the love of all things holy and good and... Clean up your dates, don't leave gaps, and explain temp, contract, or seasonal jobs. We automatically rule out poor job longevity so if you explain the reason behind short-term positions, boom!  3. CONTEXT - Give me context please! Who are you?! Whether you work at a Warehouse, in Construction, or got involved in Manufacturing... it seems that unless you are OCD, most of the time there is a LACK of information on what you actually did on your resume. Keep in mind- sometimes title doesn't match responsibilities. Add leadership skills and certificates to your timeline so we can really see what you have to offer!  4. ERRORS- *clears throat. We pay attention to spelling and grammar errors. I mean, we're here to help update all that for your future employer, but if you catch it, make the change! This includes resume gaps that we want to understand AND inconsistency in punctuation, font, and bullet points. Take a second to review before uploading.  5. SKILLS - Don't let a resume generator do all the work! I want to know what YOU specifically can do and that is not always given proper honor when you allow a hiring site to guess your skills based on your previous roles. Really think about what you have accrued besides the typical additions of "time management" and "customer service." We know you have more to offer!  Just a few thoughts! We would love to give you and your future employer the BEST CHANCE in connecting. …more

The design, layout, and content of your resume are essential for capturing the reader's attention in the first 20 to 30 seconds. It’s important to approach this task with a clear strategy, focusing on highlighting your skills and experience in a concise and engaging way. Here are a few tips to help you craft the perfect resume:  1. Highlight your accomplishments: If you cut costs, increased revenue, delivered projects ahead of time, or broke company records, your resume is the perfect place to highlight these achievements using numbers and percentages to demonstrate your impact. 2. Call out the value you would bring to the target company: Just like in sports, where the value of a new player is debated, your resume is the place to highlight the value you can bring to a potential employer, using the language that aligns with the job you're applying for. 3. Identify the ways you help solve the company’s challenges: Just like an infomercial highlights a product’s strengths to solve a problem, your resume should showcase your professional assets and demonstrate how you can address the challenges of the company you're applying to. Is your resume starting to resemble a novel? 📚 Let's trim that epic down to a compelling short story!  Here's how: 1. Prioritize the Last 10-15 Years: Focus on your most recent experience; hiring managers are more interested in what you've done lately. 2. Highlight Achievements, Not Just Duties: Showcase your impact with quantifiable results—think revenue growth, cost savings, or process improvements. 3. Remove Outdated Skills: If it's no longer relevant (e.g., obsolete software), leave it out. 4. Use a Hybrid Resume Format: A skills-focused format helps showcase expertise before listing work history. 5. Tailor for Each Job: Only include roles that are directly relevant. Remember, your resume should be a highlight reel, not a documentary. Keep it concise, relevant, and future-focused to show why you're the best fit for today's job market.  What's your biggest challenge in keeping your resume concise? Let's discuss in the comments!  …more

I hear so many engineers asking about ATS-friendly resumes, so I am going to break it down for you today!  Let's use these tips for writing an ATS-friendly resume:  ✅ Use standard headings: - Stick to common headings like “Work Experience,” “Education,” & "Skills.”  ✅ Keep formatting simple: - Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that could confuse ATS systems.  ✅ Incorporate keywords: - Strategically incorporate relevant keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements. - Try to match 70-80% of job description language  ✅ Use a professional & readable font: -  Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.  ✅ Tailor each resume: - Customize your resume for each job application to reflect the specific job requirements.  ✅ Quantify relevant experiences: - Highlight measurable achievements and impactful projects.  Critical resume mistakes to avoid:  ❌ Omit personal details: - Do not include details like age, marital status, or photographs.  ❌ Avoid complex designs: - Skip colourful, overly creative layouts that distract from the main content.  ❌ Exclude irrelevant experiences: - Focus only on relevant, recent experience to keep your resume concise.  ❌ Keep graduate resumes short: - For fresh graduates, limit your resume to one page.  Your resume is your first impression, make sure it is clear, optimized, and ATS-friendly to increase your chances of landing an interview.  ✅ Focus on readability, relevance, and measurable impact. ✅ Use relevant keywords from the job description. ✅ Keep formatting clean and simple (avoid graphics/tables). ✅ Tailor each resume for the role, one-size-fits-all won’t work. ✅ Want better results? Apply online AND network with hiring managers!  Finally, 👉 An ATS-friendly resume doesn’t just pass the ATS, it gets you noticed by recruiters! 👉 ATS is just a tool, it doesn’t make hiring decisions! 👉 ATS is not your enemy, it is a tool that helps recruiters. 👉 Stop fearing it and focus on what you can control 👉 Make your resume work for you!  DMfor any questions or mentoring support!    ______________________________________________________________________________ 🙋‍♀️I am, , I have guided over 100+ engineers! …more

Recently, I reviewed a resume so GOOD, it made me pause in the middle of my lunch & call the candidate to schedule an interview.  It wasn't just the layout or the fancy font that caught my eye; it was the clear, concise way the candidate's achievements and experiences were presented.  It was evident they had done their homework, tailoring their resume specifically for the role, making it impossible to ignore.  So, what's the recipe for a standout resume? 📄✨  1. 𝐂𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐬 𝐊𝐞𝐲: Don't send out a one-size-fits-all resume. Tailor it to the job you're applying for, highlighting the experience and skills that align with the job description.   2. 𝐂𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬: Keep it clear and to the point. Use bullet points to break down your achievements and make them easy to read.   3. 𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐒𝐩𝐞𝐚𝐤 𝐋𝐨𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐫: Quantify your achievements. But remember, simplicity doesn't mean boring.   5. 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐨𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝, 𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐨𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐀𝐠𝐚𝐢𝐧: Typos and grammatical errors can be the kiss of death for your application. Earning the trust of hiring managers is a steep mountain to climb, yet one that holds the key to effective  hashtag #recruitment. As someone who's been in the thick of it for years, I've navigated this climb and gathered invaluable insights.   Today, I want to share these time-tested tips to help you win over even the toughest of hiring managers:  1. Cultivate a partner mindset 🤝: First things first, you're not just a recruiter, but a strategic partner. Think about it. It's not just about filling a role; it's about understanding the unique requirements of a position, recognizing the team dynamic, and finding a person who fits like a glove.  2. Keep communication clear and consistent 💬: You've heard it before, and I'll say it again. Communication is key. Consistently update your hiring manager about the progress you're making, potential hiccups in the pipeline, and candidate feedback. Trust me, they'll appreciate your transparency.  3. Demonstrate market knowledge 📑: Show them you know your stuff. Keep abreast of industry trends, shifts in the job market, and salary benchmarks. Knowledge is power, and in this case, it can be the bridge to trust.  4. Go beyond the resume 📃: When you're presenting a candidate, don't just forward a . Instead, present a comprehensive view of the candidate's skills, experience, and cultural fit. Highlight why you believe they're right for the job. It's all about the details.  Keep these nuggets in your arsenal, and you'll be a hiring manager's dream in no time!  …more

Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.   Forget the usual advice.  People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.  We all know that doesn't work.  If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:  1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!  Have 20 years of experience?  Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!  Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.  Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!  2. Apply to the same job 37 times!  They'll have to notice you eventually right?  Persistence? Yes.  Stalking? That's for you to decide.  3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!  Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.  It's great for the culture!  4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.  It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!  I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.  Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share?  Let me know in the comments!  Have a great Saturday everyone!  …more

🕒 How I Review 100 Resumes in Under an Hour  Ever felt buried under a mountain of resumes? It’s easy to get overwhelmed, but there’s a faster, smarter way to sift through the noise and find the top talent. Here’s how I break it down:  1️⃣ Prioritize must-have skills: Start with non-negotiables. If the role requires Python or AWS experience, filter for it upfront.  2️⃣ Scan for relevant projects: Look for real-world examples where candidates contributed to projects similar to what you need.  3️⃣ Check for career progression: Promotions, increased responsibility, and diverse roles show growth and initiative.  4️⃣ Use keyword searches: Boolean search is your friend! Combine terms like “DevOps AND CI/CD” to narrow the pool.  5️⃣ Pre-set scorecards: Create a scoring system to stay objective. Rate candidates based on skills, experience, and key achievements. No more gut-feeling decisions!  ⚡ Pro Tip: Batch your review time—30 focused minutes beats hours of multitasking any day.  Need a breakdown of any of these steps? Let me know!👇  …more

Wrote a client's resume today. 📝  Most people overthink this step, but after writing thousands of resumes, I’ve learned a few counterintuitive truths.  Here are 3 quick contrarian resume writing tips:  1️⃣ Write less, not more. Hiring managers skim. The more you write, the less they retain. 2️⃣ You are less important than the company’s needs. The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.  NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.  START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.  INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.  FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.  END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.  Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below! …more

✨📄 Resume Building 101: Stand Out in 20 Seconds 📄✨ Did you know that employers typically spend only 20 to 30 seconds looking at a resume? Make every second count with these top tips: 1. Choose the Right Format: Highlight your experiences, skills, and abilities in a format that suits you best. A reverse chronological order is often effective, listing your most recent activities first. 2. Keep It Concise: Aim for a one-page resume with consistent formatting. Use bullet points and simple sentences for clarity. 3. Be Honest: Always be truthful. Employers verify information, and honesty is key. 4. Visual Appeal: Make your resume visually appealing to grab attention. 5. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight relevant skills and experiences. 6. Clear Objective: Include a clear resume objective to give employers insight into your interests. 7. Action Verbs: Start sentences with powerful action verbs to make your points impactful. 8. Error-Free: Ensure your resume is free of grammatical, spelling, punctuation, and typographical errors. 9. Use Keywords: Incorporate industry-specific keywords and phrases to make your resume relevant to recruiters. For example, if you're an Accounting major, include 'CPA Eligible by May 2025'. 10. Show Leadership and Achievements: Highlight any leadership roles, achievements, and organizational involvement. Make sure these are also visible on your LinkedIn profile. Remember, a well-crafted resume can make a significant difference in your job application process. Let's make your resume shine! 🌟  …more

The Truth Behind 6 Resume Myths 🔊   There’s a lot of resume “wisdom” floating around the internet—but not all of it is accurate. Let’s bust six of the most common resume myths and set the record straight:  1. Your Resume Must Be One Page Not true! If you have substantial experience, it’s okay to go up to two pages. What matters is how relevant and concise your content is.  2. Gaps in Your Resume Are Dealbreakers Life happens! As long as you address gaps confidently and show how you stayed active or grew during them, it won’t sink your chances.  3. You Always Need References Nope! Employers typically ask for references after you’ve made it through the initial stages. Keep them on hand but off your resume.  4. Your Resume Should Be "Unique" A flashy, one-of-a-kind resume isn’t necessary unless you’re in a creative field. Focus on clarity and relevance instead of gimmicks.  5. You Have to List Your Full Address The days of snail mail are over! Just list your city and state—no need for your full address.  6. Dates and Employer Names Aren’t Important Think again! Hiring managers want to know where you worked and for how long. Dates and employer names give your experience credibility. …more

👀 Is Your Resume Easy to Read?  After you’ve created your resume, take a moment to visually inspect it. Why? Because if it’s hard to read or navigate, it might not get the attention it deserves. Here’s a quick checklist to ensure it stands out: 🔍 Top-to-Bottom Flow Does your resume naturally guide the reader’s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? That’s the most critical part—if it’s hard to find, you’re doing yourself a disservice.  📂 Key Details at a Glance Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.  🎯 Communicating Accomplishments Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments you’d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.  💡 Pro Tip If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. It's one of the most common questions hiring managers have when reviewing a resume. "What's that company do?"  …more

Entry-level Resumes:  "Create a resume for an entry-level candidate with the following: {education}, {internships}, {skills}, and {projects}. Executive Resume:  "Develop an executive-level resume for {job_title} with an emphasis on {leadership}, {strategic impact}, and {revenue growth}. Sight on Keywords o Use keywords from the job description. o Incorporate industry-specific terms. 6. Research About the Company o Understand the company’s mission and values. o Familiarize yourself with their products/services. 2.   Update Resume o Tailor your resume for each job application. o Add any new skills or experiences. 3.   Align Skills with Job Roles o Highlight skills that match the job description. o Use examples that demonstrate those skills. 4.   Read Job Description Well o Identify key responsibilities and requirements. o  Ensure your resume addresses these points. Your resume gets 6 seconds.   SIX SECONDS. That’s all recruiters need...  To decide if your CV lands in the “no thanks” pile.  If your resume is sending the wrong signals, it’s game over—before you’ve even started.  Here’s how to fix it fast:  1. "I Didn’t Read the Job Posting." 🔴 Red Flag: Clichés like “detail-oriented” or “team player.” 🟢 Fix It: Mirror the job description. Use keywords and highlight specific achievements.  2. "I’m Living in the Past." 🔴 Red Flag: Listing ancient or irrelevant experience. 🟢 Fix It: Focus on the last 10 years. Keep it lean & relevant.  3. "I’m Afraid of Technology." 🔴 Red Flag: No mention of tools or platforms. 🟢 Fix It: Add your tech stack—Excel, Salesforce, or certifications. Digital fluency is mandatory.  4. "I’m Hiding Something." 🔴 Red Flag: Unexplained employment gaps. 🟢 Fix It: Fill the gaps—showcase freelancing, volunteering, or upskilling. Control the narrative.  5. "I Don’t Sweat the Details." 🔴 Red Flag: Typos, inconsistent formatting, outdated info. 🟢 Fix It: Use Grammarly. Polished resumes show you care.  6. "I Have No Results to Show." 🔴 Red Flag: Vague phrases like “managed a team” or “responsible for projects.” 🟢 Fix It: Quantify everything: “Boosted sales by 25%” > “Managed a team.”  7. "I’m Just Sending This Everywhere." 🔴 Red Flag: Generic resumes sent to every job. 🟢 Fix It: Highlight wins that match the job description.  8. "I’m Desperate." 🔴 Red Flag: Applying for every job under the sun. 🟢 Fix It: Stay focused. Align your resume to roles that tell one clear story.  🔥 Your Resume = Your Pitch.  If it’s not selling your story, it’s time for a rewrite.  What is your resume really saying about you?  ♻️ Share this to help someone today! 🔔 And followfor more. …more

Another lesson learned from responses I've received to "no thank you" emails sent to applicants: I occasionally get responses from applicants pointing out how relevant their experience is--experience not apparent in their resume. Candidates, make it easy on both sides:  * Customize your resume for every job you apply for. * Look at the skills, responsibilities, and experience in the job posting and then make sure as many of those as possible are explicitly stated in your resume (within the bounds of truth, of course). * Use easy-to-skim bullets. Don't make a recruiter squint through long paragraphs trying to understand your value. * Don't assume that a recruiter understands what your previous roles have involved. If you're applying for a job that requires phone skills, for example, spell out in your resume how you've used phone skills in previous roles.  Doing the above helps a recruiter quickly see your relevance to their job and boosts your chances of getting an interview. A win for all!   …more

Most résumés are boring and forgettable.  Here’s how to make yours stand out.   Most people treat their résumé like a history book, listing every job they’ve had and every task they’ve done.   But hiring managers don’t need a timeline, they need a reason to say YES.  Here’s how to make your résumé stand out in a way most people overlook:  🔹 Write for the Future, Not the Past Your résumé should position you for the job you WANT, not just reflect what you’ve done. Tailor your skills and accomplishments to align with the next step in your career.  🔹 Your Job Title Isn’t Enough, Show the Impact Instead of “Managed training programs,” say “Designed and implemented training programs that increased employee productivity by 30%.” Numbers tell a story.  🔹 Your Summary Shouldn’t Be Boring Avoid clichés like “hardworking professional seeking opportunities.” Instead, answer: What makes you different? Why should they hire YOU?  🔹 Remove Fluff That Wastes Space Phrases like “responsible for” or “assisted with” weaken your impact. Get straight to the result. What did you do? What happened because of it?  🔹 Make It Easy to Skim Hiring managers scan résumés in seconds. Use bold headings, bullet points, and clear formatting so they can see your value fast.  Your résumé isn’t just a document, it’s your first impression.  Make them want to know more.  Does your résumé sell your value or just list your past?  …more

📝 When writing your resume, remember to go beyond mere job descriptions (i.e., what you did day-to-day) and focus on showcasing your accomplishments.  Specifically, think about how you've contributed to your organization's success by making or saving money, furthering its mission and vision, and supporting your colleagues in doing the same.  🚀 While you can allocate a couple of sentences to outline your job responsibilities, the real value lies in emphasizing your achievements through well-crafted bullets.  Remember, your resume is not just a list of tasks you performed in previous roles. It's an opportunity to demonstrate the impact you've had on your past employers and how you can bring value to your future ones.  💼 Highlight quantifiable results: Share how your efforts led to cost savings, revenue growth, or process improvements within your team or organization.  🎯 Showcase your alignment with the company's mission and vision: Illustrate how your work contributed to advancing the organization's overall goals and objectives.  🤝 Emphasize collaboration and support: Describe instances where you collaborated with colleagues to achieve shared objectives or helped others achieve their goals.  🔍 Tailor your resume for each application: Customize your bullet points to align with the specific job requirements and showcase skills and achievements most relevant to the role.  💡 Use action verbs and metrics: Employ strong action verbs to describe your accomplishments and quantify your contributions with specific numbers, percentages, or metrics.  📈 Prove your value with real-world examples: Paint a clear picture of your impact by providing concrete examples of successful projects, initiatives, or problem-solving scenarios.  A well-crafted resume not only grabs the attention of recruiters and hiring managers but also sets you apart from other candidates by highlighting your unique contributions. So, remember, it's not just about the roles you've held; it's about what you've achieved and how that will benefit your future employer. Make every word count!  …more

Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective  To Employers: When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks: - Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction. - Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory. - Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities. - Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.  Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pause—it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.  To Job Seekers: - Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills. - Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals. - Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy. - Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.  Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. The painful truth about ATS "hacks" that no one's talking about...  I see job seekers spending countless hours: ✔️ Cramming keywords ✔️ Using white text ✔️ Creating complex tables ✔️ Testing "perfect" formatting tricks  Here's the reality: Modern ATS systems are FAR more sophisticated than you think. Those outdated hacks from 2015? They might actually be hurting your chances.  Instead, focus on what truly matters:  Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time.  Use clean, standard formatting Simple beats clever. Period. Your beautifully formatted resume means nothing if it's unreadable to human eyes.  Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.  Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. It's to reach the hiring manager's desk with a resume that makes them want to meet you.  Pro tip: Want to test your resume? Send it to yourself as a plain text file. If it's readable there, most ATS systems will handle it just fine.  Want to check your resume's ATS score? Land Your Dream Job with These Essential Resume Tips  Your resume is the first impression you make on recruiters, it’s your ticket to standing out in a competitive job market. Crafting a standout resume takes effort, but with the right approach, you can make it unforgettable. Here are some top tips to ensure your resume gets noticed:  1️⃣ Tailor Your Resume to the Job 🎯 Why it matters: Generic resumes don’t impress. Customize your resume for each role by aligning it with the job description. Highlight the skills and experiences that are most relevant to the position.  2️⃣ Highlight Relevant Experience 💼 Why it matters: Recruiters focus on what’s applicable to the job. Showcase experiences that align with the role. For unrelated roles, reframe your experience to demonstrate transferable skills.  3️⃣ Keep It Short 📝 Why it matters: Less is more in resume writing. Aim for a one- or two-page resume. Focus on concise, impactful descriptions of your skills and achievements.  4️⃣ Use Action Verbs 💪 Why it matters: Dynamic language grabs attention. Begin bullet points with action verbs like "led," "improved," "created," or "streamlined." Action verbs also help you stand out to Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS).  5️⃣ Choose the Right Format 📂 Why it matters: Your format reflects your career goals. Pick a chronological format for steady work history. Opt for a functional or hybrid format if you’re changing careers or highlighting skills.  6️⃣ Add Numbers 🔢 Why it matters: Metrics make your accomplishments tangible. Quantify your achievements (e.g., "boosted sales by 30%" or "managed a $2M budget"). Numbers help recruiters understand your impact.  7️⃣ Use a Modern, ATS-Friendly Template 📄 Why it matters: An ATS-friendly design ensures your resume gets seen. Avoid graphics, images, or complicated tables. Stick to clean, simple layouts that ATS software can easily parse.  Pro Tip: A great resume is your gateway to landing interviews. Invest time to polish it and consider professional services if needed.  …more

I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:  Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.  Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?  Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.  Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.  Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work – even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog 😊).  All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.  Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.  🏅 What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?   …more

Jeff Nevez, here with APC! I've seen countless resumes pass my desk. Unfortunately, some don’t make it to the next step for common, avoidable reasons. Here's what might be holding yours back:  🔑 Lack of Relevant Experience If your experience doesn't align with the job, recruiters may move on. Tailor your resume to highlight the most relevant skills and achievements.  📝 Poor Resume Formatting A cluttered or difficult-to-read resume can be a dealbreaker. Stick to a clean format with clear headings and bullet points.  📚 Missing Keywords Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) scan for specific keywords. If they’re missing, your resume may be filtered out before anyone sees it.  ⏳ Employment Gaps Without Explanation Gaps happen, and that’s okay—but explain them. Highlight growth during these periods, whether through learning, caregiving, or volunteering.  🎯 Generic Objective Statements Outdated or vague objectives don’t help. Use a strong professional summary to show your value upfront.  🔍 Typos and Grammar Errors Mistakes show a lack of attention to detail. Double-check or ask someone to review it for you.  ⚠️ Inconsistent or Inaccurate Information Inconsistent job titles or inflated claims raise red flags. Honesty is key.  📊 Lack of Measurable Achievements Just listing job duties isn’t enough. Show your impact using numbers, percentages, and results.  💡 By addressing these points, you’ll significantly increase your chances of getting noticed. Want more resume tips or career advice? RESPONSIBILITIES OVER ACHIEVEMENTS  ❌ "Managed projects and oversaw deadlines."  ✅ "Led 3+ cross-functional teams, delivering 7 projects on time with a 98% client satisfaction rate.”   IRRELEVANT INFO  ❌ Adding technologies you are not using anymore.  ✅ Adding information relevant to the role you’re applying for   Comment “template” - and I’ll send you this EDITABLE FIGMA TEMPLATE. Use These copy-and-paste AI Prompts to Craft a Standout Cover Letter 👇  Make a lasting impression. Get more interviews. Land your dream role!  Try these 7 prompts to supercharge your cover letter:  ✉️ Prompt 1: Personalized Opening Creator Draft an engaging introduction tailored to [Company Name]. Highlight recent initiatives, values, or achievements. Create three variations: one focused on cultural alignment, one on innovation, and one on solving key challenges. Include "connection strength" and "engagement rating" for each. Limit to 75 words. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Company insights: [Paste Research].  ✉️ Prompt 2: Qualification Alignment Mapper Analyze [Job Title] requirements and match them to my qualifications in a table format with columns for 'Requirement', 'My Experience', and 'Proof of Success'. Add match strength percentages and key talking points. Identify three standout factors that differentiate me. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 3: Success Story Crafter Generate three impactful success stories tailored to [Target Role] using the Challenge-Action-Result framework. Focus on measurable outcomes and business impact. Rate each story's strength and memorability. Keep each story concise (50 words max). My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 4: Experience-Needs Connector Create a table linking [Job Title] priorities with my skills and accomplishments. Use columns for 'Company Need', 'My Contribution', and 'Supporting Evidence'. Assign relevance and impact scores for each entry. Limit entries to 15 words each. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 5: Culture Fit Demonstrator Identify core values and cultural traits from [Company Name]. Write evidence-based statements showing alignment with their mission and ethos. Present in a table with 'Company Value', 'My Experience', and 'Specific Example'. Include authenticity ratings for each match. Company insights: [Paste Research]. My resume: [Paste Resume].  ✉️ Prompt 6: Distinct Value Communicator Write a compelling second paragraph showcasing my unique strengths for [Role]. Develop three versions emphasizing problem-solving, innovation, or team-building skills. Include measurable results and forward-looking statements. Rate differentiation level for each version. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].  ✉️ Prompt 7: Passion Statement Builder Craft an enthusiastic third paragraph expressing excitement about the opportunity at [Company Name]. Incorporate industry knowledge and company-specific insights. Create tailored versions for startups, corporate environments, or growth-stage businesses. Evaluate sincerity signals for each version. 3 Tricks to Make Your Résumé Stand Out  Recruiters receive hundreds of résumés daily, and the competition is fierce. If you want to catch their attention and land that interview, here are three simple but powerful tricks to make your résumé stand out:  1️⃣ Tailor Your Résumé to Each Job A generic résumé won’t do you any favours. Study the job description and highlight relevant skills, experience, and keywords. Show the recruiter that you’re the perfect fit for that specific role.  2️⃣ Make It Easy to Read Recruiters spend an average of 6–10 seconds scanning a résumé before deciding if they’ll read further. Use clear headings, bullet points, and a clean layout. Keep it concise—ideally one to two pages.  3️⃣ Show, Don’t Just Tell Instead of listing responsibilities, highlight your achievements. Use numbers to showcase your impact. For example, "Increased sales by 30% in six months" sounds stronger than "Responsible for sales growth." Freshers, keep it short. But for experienced folks, focus on relevance. Feature what matters to the recruiter, even if it goes beyond one page.  🚫 Myth 2: Your Resume Should Be All Pretty and Flashy  Totally wrong! Your resume isn't an art project. Keep it clean and pro. Make the format easy on the eyes, not an eye-catcher.  🚫 Myth 3: Your Resume Should Have a Photo of You  False alarm! Unless they ask, skip the photo. It's a distraction, not a necessity. Save that space for something valuable.  🚫 Myth 4: Only Paid Experience Counts  Not true! If you're a fresher with internships and projects, they matter. No need for paid gigs right away. Your skills and efforts count too.  🚫 Myth 5: You Need to Add an Objective Section  Nah, they're kinda useless. Everyone wants to apply their skills. Instead, use that space wisely. Highlight your key skills and results – make it count.   -----------------------------------------   Remember, stay informed and keep your knowledge fresh. 👀 Is Your Resume Easy to Read?  After you’ve created your resume, take a moment to visually inspect it. Why? Because if it’s hard to read or navigate, it might not get the attention it deserves. Here’s a quick checklist to ensure it stands out: 🔍 Top-to-Bottom Flow Does your resume naturally guide the reader’s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? That’s the most critical part—if it’s hard to find, you’re doing yourself a disservice.  📂 Key Details at a Glance Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.  🎯 Communicating Accomplishments Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments you’d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.  💡 Pro Tip If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. Tip of the Week: Your Resume Should Be a Movie Trailer, Not the Whole Script  If your resume reads like a generic job description, we have a problem. Hiring managers don’t want to see a list of what you were supposed to do—they want to see what you actually did.  Saying “Managed cloud infrastructure” is the resume equivalent of saying you “existed” at work. Instead, try “Optimized cloud resources to cut hosting costs by 35% while improving system uptime to 99.98%.”  See the difference? Numbers, results, and real impact make you stand out.  Think of your resume like a movie trailer—it should hook the audience, highlight the best moments, and leave them wanting more. What projects did you crush? What problems did you solve? How did your work make life easier, faster, or more efficient for your team? If your resume doesn’t make hiring managers excited to learn more, it’s time for a rewrite.  Hiring managers want problem-solvers, not a recap of job duties. Show them the action, the impact, and the results.  What’s the best resume tip that helped you land an interview? “Productive Perspective” #11  ❌Common Resume Mistakes That Can Get You Rejected Instantly!  As a reviewing countless resumes daily, I still see candidates making these avoidable mistakes. Here are some key reasons why resumes get rejected at first glance:  1. Grammatical & Spelling Errors – A resume full of typos reflects a lack of attention to detail. Proofread carefully or use tools like Grammarly.  2. Listing Every Possible Tool & Technology – Don’t just add all buzzwords to get a call. Only mention technologies you have actual hands-on experience with.  3. Over-Reliance on AI-Generated Resumes – Using AI (like ChatGPT) to refine your resume is fine, but copying generic content can make it sound impersonal and irrelevant to your real experience.  4. Frequent Job Hopping Without Explanation – If your resume shows job changes every few months or years, it raises red flags for recruiters. Address it in your profile summary if needed.  5. Vague One-Word Responsibilities – Writing generic words like “Implementation,” “Development,” or “Support” for every project doesn’t help. Be specific about your contributions.  6. Missing Project Durations & Education Year – Always mention the timeline for each project and your education year to avoid confusion about experience level.  Want to stand out? Avoid these mistakes and craft a resume that truly reflects your skills and experience!  🤔Did i miss on something? 🗣️Share your views..  …more
