With over 250 applications per job opening on average, that resume needs a strategic approach to consistently grab the attention needed to get you in the door.  So, is yours designed for easy consumption and comprehension? If you are only paying attention to what goes in it and not how it is delivered, you might have a problem.  Hiring managers and recruiters spend hours reviewing resumes, their eyes weary and strained. Respect their time by ensuring your resume is easy to read and navigate.  Here are some best practices for making your resume as readable as possible:  📜 Use a Clean Design: Stick to professional fonts (like Arial, Calibri, or Times New Roman) and avoid unnecessary graphics or images. Keep font sizes between 10 and 12 points for readability.  📜 Structure for Navigation: Use clear headings, bold job titles, and bullet points to guide the reader through your experience. Think of your resume as if it were a map. Navigation cues will help your reader find the information they need quickly.  📜 Emphasize White Space: White space isn’t wasted space, it is in fact essential for readability. Like a well-designed advertisement, a resume with balanced white space draws attention to key points and prevents the page from feeling overwhelming. Research done in the graphic design field emphasizes that white space enhances readability and legibility, allowing key information to stand out and reducing cognitive load for the reader.  📜 Tailor and Highlight: Place the most relevant achievements and skills at the top of each section. Get Your Resume Noticed  8 Key Scannable Points (and What Recruiters REALLY Want to See ) hashtag hashtag    Crafting a resume that gets past the initial screening can feel like cracking a code! Here are the top 8 things recruiters typically scan for (forget page count!):  Location: Make it easy for them to see if you're a local candidate.   Summary/Profile: Briefly showcase your key experiences and what makes you stand out.   Company Name (1-3 sentence summary): Quickly explain what the company did (e.g., "Developed educational software for children" or "Managed social media campaigns for a non-profit").   Title: Highlight the specific role you held (use the same wording as the job description if possible).   Dates: Be transparent about your employment history, including month and year (short stints are okay!).   Metrics: Quantify your achievements whenever possible (e.g., "Increased website traffic by 20%"). Numbers grab attention!   Education: Include it if it's relevant to the job (essential for some roles like doctors or engineers).   Technical Skills (if applicable): List relevant skills, but showcase them further in your bullet points with specific examples.   What else are recruiters looking for?  While "soft skills" aren't the answer this time, here are some recruiter favorites: Clear and concise writing (avoid typos!) ️  Strong action verbs that showcase your achievements (e.g., "spearheaded," "managed," "increased")  Tailored content that speaks directly to the job description   P.S. Big Company Work Experience? Be Specific!  If you worked for a giant like Google, mention the specific division or function (e.g., "Google Search Ads team" or "Google Cloud Platform engineering"). This clarifies your unique experience within the vast company.   By focusing on these key elements, you can craft a resume that gets noticed and lands you that interview! …more

🚀 5 Common Writing Mistakes (And How to Fix Them!) ✍️  Great content isn’t just about writing—it’s about writing well. Yet, many writers (even experienced ones) fall into these common traps: ❌ 1. Fluffy Introductions 👉 Mistake: Taking too long to get to the point. ✅ Fix: Hook your reader in the first sentence! Start with a bold statement, a stat, or a question. ❌ 2. Overusing Jargon 👉 Mistake: Using complex terms that confuse readers. ✅ Fix: Write like you're explaining to a 10-year-old. Keep it clear and concise. ❌ 3. Writing Without Structure 👉 Mistake: Huge blocks of text that scare readers away. ✅ Fix: Use headings, bullet points, and short paragraphs to improve readability. ❌ 4. Forgetting SEO 👉 Mistake: Writing great content but ignoring keywords. ✅ Fix: Research and naturally integrate relevant keywords to improve rankings. ❌ 5. Weak Call to Action (CTA) 👉 Mistake: Leaving readers without a next step. ✅ Fix: End with a clear CTA—whether it’s subscribing, sharing, or commenting. 🚀 Pro Tip: Writing is a skill that improves with practice. Keep refining, keep learning! 👉 What’s one writing mistake you’ve learned to avoid? Drop it in the comments! ⬇️    …more

Your IT/tech job descriptions might be turning candidates away. 🛑  This is how to fix them! ✅  ➡️ 1. Start with a clear job title Avoid jargon or creative titles that confuse candidates. A straightforward job title like "Software Engineer" performs better in search results and aligns with candidate expectations.  ➡️ 2. Include a strong opening summary Summarize the role in 2-3 sentences. Focus on the core purpose of the job and how it contributes to the company’s goals, keeping it concise and engaging.  ➡️ 3. Outline key responsibilities clearly List the main tasks in bullet points. Be specific to avoid ambiguity—avoid general phrases like "handle IT projects" and specify the exact responsibilities.  ➡️ 4. Focus on day-to-day activities Paint a picture of a typical day in the role. This helps candidates visualize the job and assess if it's the right fit for them.  ➡️ 5. Specify required skills and technologies Clearly list must-have technical skills, such as Python, SQL, or AWS. This filters candidates early and saves time for both parties.  ➡️ 6. Differentiate between ‘required’ and ‘preferred’ skills Clearly label "must-have" versus "nice-to-have" skills. This helps attract qualified applicants while keeping the door open for those who may have potential.  ➡️ 7. Set realistic expectations for experience levels Be precise about the experience level required—whether it's entry-level or senior. Avoid broad terms like "junior" or "experienced" without clear year-based guidelines.  ➡️ 8. Explain the purpose of the role Describe why the role exists and how it fits into the company's broader goals. This provides context and meaning, motivating the right candidates to apply.  ➡️ 9. Highlight career growth opportunities Mention internal development programs or career paths. Candidates want to know how they can progress within your company, especially in a fast-paced industry like IT.  ➡️ 10. Provide a clear reporting structure State who the candidate will report to. This helps candidates understand where the role fits in the organizational hierarchy and clarifies team dynamics.  ... and 14 further must-read tips in the carousel below!  …more

Did you recently get passed over for a role you thought you were a perfect fit for? Job hunting can be a challenging journey, and rejection, while tough, is often part of the process. Instead of letting frustration take over, take a step back and assess your approach. Are there areas where you could refine your strategy? Below are a few insights that might help you turn things around and boost your chances for success.  1. Are You Aiming Too High? One common mistake candidates make is applying for roles that may be slightly out of reach. It’s natural to want to push for the next level in your career, but are your qualifications truly aligned with the position you’re applying for?  If you find yourself consistently passed over for roles that require more experience or a broader skill set, it might be time to reassess and realign. Consider seeking a company with a clear advancement policy or a position that will help bridge the gap between where you are now and where you want to go. Remember: career growth is a marathon, not a sprint.  2. Have You Updated and Tailored Your Resume? Your resume is the first impression you make on potential employers. Have you taken the time to thoroughly update it before submitting your applications? A rushed, generic resume could be the reason you’re not getting callbacks.  Think carefully about the content you’re showcasing. Are you just listing broad job duties, or are you clearly communicating your achievements and the value you've added in your previous roles? Employers want to see specific examples of how you’ve contributed to the success of your past organizations. Instead of simply stating “responsible for managing a team,” try adding more depth: “Led a team of 8 to successfully implement a project that resulted in a 15% increase in operational efficiency.”  Refine each bullet point, focusing on accomplishments and measurable outcomes that highlight your unique value.  3. Are You Preparing for Interviews? Winging it simply won’t cut it. The competition is fierce, and preparation is key. If you’re not taking the time to prepare for interviews, you’re missing out on one of your best chances to shine.  Think about your most significant career achievements—those moments that truly made an impact at your previous companies. Be ready to share specific metrics, numbers, and examples that demonstrate your value.  It’s also important to keep your answers concise. Hiring managers often have limited time, so make sure you’re answering questions thoroughly without going off on tangents. Practice telling your stories in a clear, impactful way that highlights your expertise while remaining focused on the relevant details.  4. Bonus: Explore Interview Tips from Experts If you’re feeling stuck or unsure about how to best prepare for interviews, consider checking out resources like Janet Jones’ profile for a series of valuable tips on acing interviews. …more

Your resume gets 6 seconds.   SIX SECONDS. That’s all recruiters need...  To decide if your CV lands in the “no thanks” pile.  If your resume is sending the wrong signals, it’s game over—before you’ve even started.  Here’s how to fix it fast:  1. "I Didn’t Read the Job Posting." 🔴 Red Flag: Clichés like “detail-oriented” or “team player.” 🟢 Fix It: Mirror the job description. Use keywords and highlight specific achievements.  2. "I’m Living in the Past." 🔴 Red Flag: Listing ancient or irrelevant experience. 🟢 Fix It: Focus on the last 10 years. Keep it lean & relevant.  3. "I’m Afraid of Technology." 🔴 Red Flag: No mention of tools or platforms. 🟢 Fix It: Add your tech stack—Excel, Salesforce, or certifications. Digital fluency is mandatory.  4. "I’m Hiding Something." 🔴 Red Flag: Unexplained employment gaps. 🟢 Fix It: Fill the gaps—showcase freelancing, volunteering, or upskilling. Control the narrative.  5. "I Don’t Sweat the Details." 🔴 Red Flag: Typos, inconsistent formatting, outdated info. 🟢 Fix It: Use Grammarly. Polished resumes show you care.  6. "I Have No Results to Show." 🔴 Red Flag: Vague phrases like “managed a team” or “responsible for projects.” 🟢 Fix It: Quantify everything: “Boosted sales by 25%” > “Managed a team.”  7. "I’m Just Sending This Everywhere." 🔴 Red Flag: Generic resumes sent to every job. 🟢 Fix It: Highlight wins that match the job description.  8. "I’m Desperate." 🔴 Red Flag: Applying for every job under the sun. 🟢 Fix It: Stay focused. Align your resume to roles that tell one clear story.  🔥 Your Resume = Your Pitch.  If it’s not selling your story, it’s time for a rewrite.  What is your resume really saying about you?  ♻️ Share this to help someone today! 🔔 And followfor more. …more

Here are my top tips to make your resume stand out!! The goal is clarity and readability. A well-organised, professional resume creates a positive first impression and helps employers quickly see why you're a strong candidate.  Over the next few weeks, I'll also provide tips on what to avoid including in your resume and seek your input on some debatable topics you might believe should be included.  START WITH THE BASICS - Create a clear, professional header with your name, in a larger font, (your header is the first thing employers will notice) and include in a smaller font your phone number and email for easy readability.  SUMMARY - Include a brief summary under your header highlighting your skills, experience, and career goals to showcase and make a strong first impression that you’re the right fit for the job.  SKILLS - Highlight relevant expertise here, tailoring them to the job description and including transferable skills.  HIGHLIGHT YOUR ACHIEVEMENTS AND EDUCATION- List your degrees, certifications, courses, languages, awards, key achievements, professional memberships, accreditations, and volunteer work.  SOFTWARE – List all software programs you’ve used in a separate section under your achievements.  CAREER SUMMARY TABLE – Provide a VERY BRIEF snapshot of your past roles under your listed software, including job title, company, and dates worked. Start with your most recent roles, and include your expanded detailed tasks separately on the following pages.  EMPLOYMENT HISTORY ⦿ Include company name, job title, promotions, exact dates, and if a permanent or a contract role. ⦿ Keep your resume concise - 1-3 pages max, or up to 4 if you have over 20 years of experience. List the last 15 years of experience in reverse order, condensing older roles past 15 years unless they are relevant to the job. ⦿ Dot point tasks - Write in first person without "I," e.g., “Scheduled and organised client appointments.” ⦿ Make it precise and measurable - saying “increased sales by 20%” is more impactful than “improved sales”, instead of “updating clients,” say “updated 60 clients weekly.” ⦿ Include specific skills and highlight keywords from the job description in your resume to showcase your relevant experience. ⦿ Briefly explain employment gaps, whether due to travel, study, COVID, redundancy, family, or other reasons.  FORMATTING - Use a consistent 10-12 pt font, bold headers only, bullet points for tasks, and a professional font like Times New Roman or Arial. If using lines, keep them thin and light-coloured.  PROOFREAD – Print or read your resume aloud to spot errors, and have a detail-oriented friend review it.  FINISHING TOUCHES - Name it properly, using your name followed by "Resume” and save your resume as a PDF to maintain its format.  "MOST IMPORTANTLY", BE HONEST - Honesty is key to your resume. Dishonesty can harm your chances and reputation. Stay truthful! …more

In today’s competitive job market, your resume is often your first impression with potential employers—and it needs to shine. But what if writing isn’t your strength? That’s where hiring a professional resume writer can be a game-changer. However, not all resume writers are created equal, and investing in the wrong one could leave you frustrated or, worse, still unemployed.  Before you commit, here are three essential questions to ask to ensure you’re making the right choice:  1. What is their experience and expertise? Not every resume writer understands your specific field or career goals. Ask about their professional background and how long they’ve been writing resumes. Look for someone who understands your industry and has a proven track record of success. Bonus points if they’ve worked in recruiting or HR—they’ll have insider knowledge of what hiring managers are looking for.  2. How do they tailor resumes to individual clients? Avoid writers who rely on generic templates or canned phrases. A great resume writer will ask in-depth questions about your experience, achievements, and career goals. Their goal should be to tell your unique story while ensuring your resume passes applicant tracking systems (ATS). Be wary of anyone who promises a one-size-fits-all approach.  3. Can they provide examples, reviews, or testimonials? Reputable resume writers will gladly share client testimonials or samples of their work. Seeing evidence of their ability to produce results can give you peace of mind. If they’re unwilling to provide this, it might be a red flag. ________________________________  A resume is an investment in your career, and choosing the right professional can make all the difference. Asking these questions ensures that you’re selecting someone who understands your needs and can deliver real value.  Want even more tips on hiring the best resume writer? "You’re Not Getting Hired Because You’re Forgetting This ONE Thing"  Most job seekers are stuck in a never-ending loop: Apply. Wait. Hope. Repeat.  And when they don’t get hired, they blame the economy, the job market, or even bad luck. But here’s the truth: It’s not the market. It’s your strategy. Here’s what top recruiters won’t tell you: Your resume isn’t just a piece of paper—it’s your business card for a six-figure opportunity. Yet, most job seekers treat it like a last-minute college essay. Think about this: Would Apple sell an iPhone in a plain cardboard box? Would Nike slap a logo on a plain sneaker and hope for the best? No. They tell a story. They highlight the value. They sell the vision. Now, let me ask you this: Does your resume sell YOU as the premium, top-tier professional you are? Or is it just a list of tasks you did 3 years ago? Because here’s the thing: recruiters don’t read resumes, they SKIM. And if you can’t grab their attention in 6 seconds, you’re already in the “no” pile. Here’s what to do instead: Tell a story: Don’t just list responsibilities—show results. Instead of “Managed a team,” write, “Led a team of 10 to increase productivity by 25% in 6 months.” Make it skimmable: Use bullet points, bold key achievements, and highlight metrics. Position yourself as the solution: Every job listing is a problem. Your resume should scream, “I’m the answer!”  Stop thinking like an applicant and start thinking like a business. Because here’s the hard truth: There is no success with “almost.” Either you’re the obvious choice—or you’re invisible.  If you’ve been struggling to land interviews, it’s not the job—it’s the approach. Fix that, and watch doors open.  What’s stopping you from leveling up your resume today? Let’s talk!  …more

Choose the Right Format: Highlight your experiences, skills, and abilities in a format that suits you best. Visual Appeal: Make your resume visually appealing to grab attention. 5. Tailor Your Resume: Customize your resume for each job application. Highlight relevant skills and experiences. 6. Clear Objective: Include a clear resume objective to give employers insight into your interests. 7. Action Verbs: Start sentences with powerful action verbs to make your points impactful. 8. Error-Free: Ensure your resume is free of grammatical, spelling, punctuation, and typographical errors. 9. Use Keywords: Incorporate industry-specific keywords and phrases to make your resume relevant to recruiters. For example, if you're an Accounting major, include 'CPA Eligible by May 2025'. 10. Show Leadership and Achievements: Highlight any leadership roles, achievements, and organizational involvement. Make sure these are also visible on your LinkedIn profile. Here are some common resume pitfalls transitioning military job seekers fall into:  🚩 1. The ‘One-Size-Fits-All’ Resume  Using the same generic resume for every job application is a surefire way to get ignored.  Solution: Tailor your resume to each job by aligning your skills and experience with the job description.  🚩 2. No Metrics, No Proof  Saying you "improved processes" in the military is vague. Saying you "increased efficiency by 30% and reduced costs by $50K" is impactful.  Solution: Use quantifiable achievements to show your value.  🚩 3. The Job Description Copy-Paste Trap  Regurgitating your job duties from a military or corporate role isn't compelling.  Solution: Translate responsibilities into accomplishments. Hiring managers want to know how you made an impact, not just what you were assigned to do. Make sure to use action verbs, metrics, and show results.  🚩 4. Too Much Military/Career Jargon  Don't use military jargon and acronyms that civilians don't understand. If your resume reads like a mission report, it won’t resonate with civilian recruiters.  Solution: Simplify terminology and explain how your skills transfer to the industry you’re targeting.  🚩 5. Keyword Deficiency  Many resumes get rejected by recruiters because you are not proving how you meet the skills nor address the key words listed in the job description.  Solution: Don't just list all of your previous job responsibilities, use relevant industry keywords and skills from the job description, and SHOW how you've done THAT thing they want you to know how to do.  A resume isn’t just a piece of paper; it’s your personal marketing document.  Avoid these mistakes, and you’ll get closer to landing an interview.  Maloney out! ✌     …more

I hear so many engineers asking about ATS-friendly resumes, so I am going to break it down for you today!  Let's use these tips for writing an ATS-friendly resume:  ✅ Use standard headings: - Stick to common headings like “Work Experience,” “Education,” & "Skills.”  ✅ Keep formatting simple: - Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that could confuse ATS systems.  ✅ Incorporate keywords: - Strategically incorporate relevant keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements. - Try to match 70-80% of job description language  ✅ Use a professional & readable font: -  Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.  ✅ Tailor each resume: - Customize your resume for each job application to reflect the specific job requirements.  ✅ Quantify relevant experiences: - Highlight measurable achievements and impactful projects.  Critical resume mistakes to avoid:  ❌ Omit personal details: - Do not include details like age, marital status, or photographs.  ❌ Avoid complex designs: - Skip colourful, overly creative layouts that distract from the main content.  ❌ Exclude irrelevant experiences: - Focus only on relevant, recent experience to keep your resume concise.  ❌ Keep graduate resumes short: - For fresh graduates, limit your resume to one page.  Your resume is your first impression, make sure it is clear, optimized, and ATS-friendly to increase your chances of landing an interview.  ✅ Focus on readability, relevance, and measurable impact. ✅ Use relevant keywords from the job description. ✅ Keep formatting clean and simple (avoid graphics/tables). ✅ Tailor each resume for the role, one-size-fits-all won’t work. ✅ Want better results? Apply online AND network with hiring managers!  Finally, 👉 An ATS-friendly resume doesn’t just pass the ATS, it gets you noticed by recruiters! 👉 ATS is just a tool, it doesn’t make hiring decisions! 👉 ATS is not your enemy, it is a tool that helps recruiters. 👉 Stop fearing it and focus on what you can control 👉 Make your resume work for you! Irrelevant Buzzwords  ❌ Results-driven sales professional with a proven track record. ✅️ Increased sales revenue by 30% in Q2 2023 through targeted client outreach and strategic upselling.  2. The Truth Behind 6 Resume Myths 🔊   There’s a lot of resume “wisdom” floating around the internet—but not all of it is accurate. Let’s bust six of the most common resume myths and set the record straight:  1. Your Resume Must Be One Page Not true! If you have substantial experience, it’s okay to go up to two pages. What matters is how relevant and concise your content is.  2. Gaps in Your Resume Are Dealbreakers Life happens! As long as you address gaps confidently and show how you stayed active or grew during them, it won’t sink your chances.  3. You Always Need References Nope! Employers typically ask for references after you’ve made it through the initial stages. Keep them on hand but off your resume.  4. Your Resume Should Be "Unique" A flashy, one-of-a-kind resume isn’t necessary unless you’re in a creative field. Focus on clarity and relevance instead of gimmicks.  5. You Have to List Your Full Address The days of snail mail are over! Just list your city and state—no need for your full address.  6. Dates and Employer Names Aren’t Important Think again! Hiring managers want to know where you worked and for how long. Dates and employer names give your experience credibility. …more

When I started looking for a job, people said I should apply to a lot of them. But it didn't work out that way. I applied to many jobs and often got no response.  Why? Because when we rush, we sometimes miss important details about what the job needs. It's like trying to hit a target without looking.  Instead of applying to tons of jobs randomly, it's better to focus on a few. Take time to understand what the job is about and what the company wants. Then, change your resume to match that. Make it fit what the company is looking for.  It's not about sending out a bunch of resumes—it's about sending the right ones. Quality is more important than quantity. If you match your resume with the job, you're more likely to get a call.  So, don't worry about applying everywhere. It's not a race. Take your time, understand the job, and then make your move. 📄 Resume Tips from a Recruiter (Take Them or Leave Them - could be my opinions only, so I welcome any other recruiters to chime in!)  I’ve been deep in resume reviews over the past few weeks, and a few things have stood out. So, in the spirit of kindness and humor, here are some unsolicited tips to (hopefully) help you stand out in the best way possible:  🎨 Go easy on the colors. A small splash of color? Cool. A rainbow? Distracting. Subtle and professional is the way to go. 📜 Get to the good stuff quickly. I promise, most recruiters don’t spend much time on those paragraphs or “highlight” sections at the top. Put your experience front and center—I want to see what you’ve done without scrolling through a novel first. ⚠️ Meet the minimum requirements (and be honest). If the role requires X, Y, and Z, please have X, Y, and Z. And lying on preliminary questions? Just don’t. It’s awkward for everyone. 📊 Skip the charts, graphs, and graphics. They look fancy, but honestly, I usually scroll right past them. They don’t always add the value you think they do. ✂️ Less is more. A focused, impactful resume beats one crammed with every single task you’ve ever done. Prioritize metrics and achievements—they’re your best friends. 📸 No pictures, please. That space is better used for you—your experience, skills, and what makes you a great candidate. 💡 I know the job market is tough right now, and it can be hard to know what works. I hope these tips are helpful as you polish up your resume. And know this: I’m rooting for you all! Good luck out there—you’ve got this! 💪 …more

CV/Resume Building: Your First Step to Career Success   Your CV is often the first impression you make with a potential employer. Yet, many job seekers find themselves struggling with screening tests and not getting the calls they hope for. Instead of spending big on CV-building services, I believe the real investment is in time—and leveraging accessible tools like Canva, Adobe, or even simple MS Word. Here are a few key tips to help you boost your CV’s chances of passing those screening hurdles:  1. Keep it Precise - Especially for freshers, it’s tempting to include everything. But remember, less is more. Seek advice from professionals in your field or a consultant to streamline your content and keep it relevant.  2. Leverage AI Tools - Don’t miss out on the power of design! Use AI platforms to give your CV a polished, modern look. Plenty of templates are available, and a well-designed CV stands out.  3. Formatting Matters - Ensure your CV is easy to read. Poor formatting—like mismatched fonts, inconsistent alignments, and heavy borders—can overwhelm the reader. Keep it clean and simple.  4. Spell Check, Always - A CV with spelling or grammatical errors sends the wrong message. Always double-check and, if possible, ask someone else to review it too.  5. Highlight Relevant Interests & Achievements - Tailor your CV to the role you're applying for. Sure, your singing talent is great, but if you’re applying for a finance role, highlighting your interest in business, finance, or the stock market will capture the recruiter’s attention.  || Brownie Tip ||  Use an ATS-Friendly Format - Here's a tip most people don't know—make sure your CV is ATS-friendly (Applicant Tracking System). Many companies use ATS to filter CVs before they even reach a hiring manager. Stick to standard fonts, avoid images or complex formatting, and use keywords from the job description to increase your chances of passing the automated screening.  Remember, a well-crafted CV isn’t just a list of qualifications—it’s your story in a nutshell. Spend the time to make it shine, and you’ll find yourself one step closer to that dream job. ✨ Use Your Words Wisely – Especially on Your Resume! ✨ Have you ever been told to use your words wisely? This advice doesn’t just apply to conversations—it’s crucial when crafting your resume. When I come across a resume packed with words, no matter how well-written, it often misses the mark. Why? It doesn’t tell your story. A resume like that could belong to anyone. To make your resume uniquely yours, focus on these key elements: 🔹 Scope: Describe your role—what was the scale of your responsibilities? What volume or team size did you manage? 🔹 Success: Highlight your achievements. What results did you deliver? What makes you stand out? 🔹 Recognition: Were you the “Manager of the Year”? The go-to person for a major initiative? Share it! Quantify your accomplishments with numbers, symbols, KPIs, and specifics to show your impact. Once you master this, you’ll never view resumes the same way again. Let’s compare two examples: 1️⃣ Strategic leader, hands-on with the team, developing client-centric initiatives to deliver an exceptional client experience. 2️⃣ Strategic leader, motivating teams to deliver exceptional service, resulting in a 14% sales increase YOY and growing appointment business from 8% to 17% of total sales. The second example tells a story. It’s clear, measurable, and impactful—and it speaks volumes about the candidate's contributions. 💡 Remember: Your resume should showcase your unique journey, not just a generic job description. What are your tips for crafting a standout resume? Share below—I’d love to hear your thoughts! …more

There is one phrase you should NEVER say to someone who is unemployed due to a layoff or something outside of their control.  "Enjoy your time off!"  Ah yes....because losing your job is the all expenses paid vacation that NOBODY asked for.  Let's be real:  ❌ Bills don't take a vacation. Rent, groceries, and student loans didn’t seem to get the memo that you're “off work.”  ❌ Job searching is a full-time job. Updating resumes, networking, and applying to 10-15 jobs a day isn't sipping margaritas on the beach.  ❌ Stress levels are high when you are unemployed and "relaxing" is tough when you are wondering how long your savings account will last.  Instead of telling someone to "enjoy" their time off, try saying this instead:  ✅ "How can I support you?" ✅ "Who can I introduce you to in my network that can help?" ✅ "If you need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out."  Being unemployed is anything but a vacation.  These jobseekers didn't ask for this time off.  They want to get back to work. DEAR JOB SEEKERS  THIS IS WHAT INCREASES YOUR CV SCORE ON THE APPLICANT TRACKING SYSTEM (ATS)  1) SKILLS: You can either have skills in your career objective, job bullet points, separate section or you can have skills in all the above mentioned.  2) LINKEDIN URL: Adding a hyperlink to your Linkedin Profile will help you share information about yourself that might be too much for your CV.  3) CONTACT NUMBER AND E-MAIL ADDRESS Tip: Employers will use either of these two to communicate, make sure the email address spelling is correct and the numbers aren’t swapped around.  4) FILE NAME: Always use your First Name and Surname, using anything else might cause your CV to be discarded or marked off as suspicious.  5) FILE SIZE The file must be under 2 mb. If your CV is bigger than 2 mb you need to remove attachments (copies of qualifications, cover page pictures, photos) or simply re-save it in a different format that will allow for file compression.  6) FILE TYPE: The recommended file type to use is PDF (Not scanned), you must be able to highlight the text. Word can be used as well but PDF will cause the least problems.  7) DATE FORMATTING: Include the month and year for both the start and the end date, the most recent experience being at the top going down.  Have a productive day job seekers, you’re all winners for not giving up!  …more

Recruiters don’t read resumes—they scan them.  That means if yours doesn’t grab attention in seconds, it’s getting skipped.  So, what actually makes a recruiter stop and take a second look?  Here’s a breakdown of how they think:  1️⃣ The 6-Second Rule → Recruiters aren’t reading essays. They skim for key details.  2️⃣ Your Top Half Matters Most → Name, title, contact info, LinkedIn and a compelling professional summary should be on the top.  3️⃣ Strategic Keywords → Use industry-specific terms in your headline and summary. If they don’t see relevant skills fast, you’re out.  4️⃣ Showcase Your Expertise → Your headline should highlight what you bring to the table, not just your job title.  5️⃣ Clean, Readable Formatting → If your resume looks cluttered, it won’t get read. Stick to clear fonts, white space, and a structured layout.  Think of your resume as a first impression. If it doesn’t catch attention in 6 seconds, it’s time for a revamp. The secret to stress-free resume writing? Break it into these 3 steps.  One of the biggest mistakes professionals make when job hunting is trying to do everything at once when it comes to their resume—creating, curating, and tailoring all in one sitting.  The result? Frustration, burnout, and a resume that doesn’t do justice to your accomplishments.  Here’s how to simplify the process and build resumes that work—without wasting time or energy.  1️⃣ Create Your Master Resume Start with a "base resume"—a document that lists everything you’ve done. Jobs, projects, achievements, responsibilities—get it all down without worrying about formatting or structure. The goal? To create a comprehensive record of your career history.  2️⃣ Curate for Clarity Now, trim it down. Organize your experience by grouping similar accomplishments and focusing on the most relevant wins. Think about the roles you’re targeting—what will make you stand out to recruiters or hiring managers?  3️⃣ Craft for Each Role This is where you shine! Use your curated content to craft tailored resumes that match specific job descriptions. Highlight the top 10% of your experience that aligns 100% with the job. Tools like’s AI Resume Builder make this step faster and easier by helping you extract relevant keywords and score how well your resume matches the job.  Breaking down the resume-writing process not only saves you time but ensures you’re always putting your best foot forward.  What’s your biggest challenge when it comes to writing your resume? 🔹 Mastering CV & Resume Writing: Stand Out in Your Career Journey!🔹  Crafting an Impactful CV & Resume: Your Key to Career Success!  A well-structured CV (Curriculum Vitae) and Resume can make a significant difference in securing job opportunities. Whether you're applying for academic positions, research roles, or industry jobs, tailoring your document to highlight your skills, achievements, and experiences is essential.  🔹 Key Differences Between a CV and a Resume:  ✅ CV: A detailed document (2+ pages) covering academic background, research, publications, and professional experiences—ideal for research, academia, and fellowships.  ✅ Resume: A concise (1-2 pages) summary of skills, work experience, and key accomplishments—best suited for industry positions and corporate jobs.  🔹 Essential Tips for Writing an Outstanding CV/Resume:  📝 Clarity & Structure: Use clear headings, bullet points, and a professional font for easy readability.  🎯 Tailor to the Job: Highlight relevant skills and experiences that align with the position.  📊 Quantify Achievements: Use numbers and data to demonstrate impact (e.g., "Increased lab efficiency by 30% through optimized protocols.").  💡 Professional Summary: A strong opening statement should showcase your expertise and career goals.  🚀 Use Action Words: Words like "Led," "Developed," "Implemented," and "Achieved" make your contributions stand out.  ✅ Proofread & Format: Eliminate typos, maintain a clean, professional layout, and ensure consistency in formatting.  A well-crafted CV/Resume not only opens doors but also tells your unique career story. I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:  Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.  Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?  Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.  Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.  Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work – even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog 😊).  All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.  Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.  🏅 What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?   …more

The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.  NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.  START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.  INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.  FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.  END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.  Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below! …more

I reviewed 4,000+ resumes last year. Here’s an anonymized Software Engineer resume. Let's roast it together ➡️   It’s a good resume, but small changes can double their chances of landing interviews.  Recruiters spend 6 (!) seconds per resume, so the first impression matters.   Some of the most common mistakes and what to do instead:  OVERDESIGNING  ❌ Using progress bars, decorative elements, overdesigning  ✅ Keeping design as simple as possible   DESIGNING FOR READING, NOT SCANNING  ❌ Long paragraphs, less bulleted lists  ✅ Bulleted lists, using the bold or italic font to highlight some experiences   SHORT EXPERIENCE DESCRIPTIONS  ❌ Focusing too much on education, certifications, etc.  ✅ Experience description should take up to 70-80% of the resume   NO COMPANY DESCRIPTIONS  ❌ Listing company names without context.  ✅ Adding 1-sentence company/product descriptions.   RESPONSIBILITIES OVER ACHIEVEMENTS  ❌ "Managed projects and oversaw deadlines."  ✅ "Led 3+ cross-functional teams, delivering 7 projects on time with a 98% client satisfaction rate.”   IRRELEVANT INFO  ❌ Adding technologies you are not using anymore.  ✅ Adding information relevant to the role you’re applying for   Comment “template” - and I’ll send you this EDITABLE FIGMA TEMPLATE. Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.   Forget the usual advice.  People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.  We all know that doesn't work.  If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:  1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!  Have 20 years of experience?  Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!  Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.  Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!  2. Apply to the same job 37 times!  They'll have to notice you eventually right?  Persistence? Yes.  Stalking? That's for you to decide.  3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!  Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.  It's great for the culture!  4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.  It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!  I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.  Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share? The painful truth about ATS "hacks" that no one's talking about...  I see job seekers spending countless hours: ✔️ Cramming keywords ✔️ Using white text ✔️ Creating complex tables ✔️ Testing "perfect" formatting tricks  Here's the reality: Modern ATS systems are FAR more sophisticated than you think. Those outdated hacks from 2015? They might actually be hurting your chances.  Instead, focus on what truly matters:  Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time.  Use clean, standard formatting Simple beats clever. Period. Your beautifully formatted resume means nothing if it's unreadable to human eyes.  Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.  Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. It's to reach the hiring manager's desk with a resume that makes them want to meet you.  Pro tip: Want to test your resume? Send it to yourself as a plain text file. If it's readable there, most ATS systems will handle it just fine.  Want to check your resume's ATS score? I've seen tons of resumes. Here are some common pitfalls I've seen:  1️⃣ Overloading with Text: Keep it clean and concise. Highlight your top achievements instead of listing every responsibility individually.  2️⃣ Skipping Keywords: Tailor your resume to the job by using keywords from the posting. Yes, this is an extra step, but it's worth it.  3️⃣ Generic Summaries: Customize your summary to show how you bring unique value to the role that you're applying for.  4️⃣ Ignoring Metrics: Use numbers to show impact. For example: "Increased efficiency by 30%" is much stronger than "Improved processes."  5️⃣ Formats: Resumes should be sleek and ATS-friendly. Stick to a design that’s easy to read. 🕒 How I Review 100 Resumes in Under an Hour  Ever felt buried under a mountain of resumes? It’s easy to get overwhelmed, but there’s a faster, smarter way to sift through the noise and find the top talent. Here’s how I break it down:  1️⃣ Prioritize must-have skills: Start with non-negotiables. If the role requires Python or AWS experience, filter for it upfront.  2️⃣ Scan for relevant projects: Look for real-world examples where candidates contributed to projects similar to what you need.  3️⃣ Check for career progression: Promotions, increased responsibility, and diverse roles show growth and initiative.  4️⃣ Use keyword searches: Boolean search is your friend! Combine terms like “DevOps AND CI/CD” to narrow the pool.  5️⃣ Pre-set scorecards: Create a scoring system to stay objective. Rate candidates based on skills, experience, and key achievements. Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective  To Employers: When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks: - Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction. - Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory. - Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities. - Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.  Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pause—it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.  To Job Seekers: - Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills. - Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals. - Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy. - Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.  Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. 12 ways to email like a boss (even if you aren’t one)  Being too nice in emails weakens your message. It makes people brush off your requests.  ----  Here’s a tool to create a professional resume that stands out and passes ATS filters*: 👉🏻  ----  Here are 12 email responses to sound more confident:  Addressing a Delay ❌ "Sorry for the delay." ✅ "Thank you for your patience."  Acknowledging a Mistake ❌ "Sorry I missed that." ✅ "Thank you for bringing this to my attention."  Responding to Appreciation ❌ "No worries." ✅ "I’m always happy to assist."  Following Up on Progress ❌ "Just checking in." ✅ "When can I expect an update?"   Ensuring Clarity ❌ "Hopefully that makes sense?" ✅ "Please let me know if you have any questions."  Considering New Ideas ❌ "Maybe we can consider..." ✅ "Let's explore additional options."  Requesting Feedback ❌ "Let me know what you think." ✅ "I’d appreciate your feedback."  Asking for a Review ❌ "If it’s not too much trouble..." ✅ "Could you please take a look and advise?"   Setting Expectations ❌ "I’ll try to get it done by Friday." ✅ "I will have it done by Friday."  Clarifying a Point ❌ "I’m not sure, but..." ✅ "Based on my understanding..."  Addressing a Concern ❌ "I’m a little worried about that." ✅ "There are some concerns we should address."  Proposing a Meeting ❌ "Let me know when you’re free." ✅ "Would you be available to discuss this?"  The right words can change how others respond to you. Choose them wisely and see better results. A resume is a document that summarizes your skills, experience, and education. It is typically used to apply for jobs. Here are some tips on how to write a resume: * Choose a format. -‐----------------‐-‐------------- There are three main resume formats: chronological, functional, and combination. A chronological resume lists your work experience in reverse chronological order. A functional resume focuses on your skills and abilities. A combination resume combines elements of both chronological and functional resumes.  * Start with your contact information. --------------------------------------------------------------- This includes your name, address, phone number, and email address. * Write a resume objective or summary. A resume objective is a statement of your career goals. A resume summary is a brief overview of your skills and experience.  * List your work experience. ----------------‐------------------------------- For each job, include the company name, job title, dates of employment, and a brief description of your responsibilities.  * List your education. ------------------------------------- Include the name of the school, degree earned, and graduation date.  * List your skills. ------------------------------ This can include both hard skills (such as computer skills) and soft skills (such as communication skills).  * Proofread your resume carefully. ----------------‐----------------------------------------- Make sure there are no typos or grammatical errors.  * Tailor your resume to the specific job you are applying for. ------------------‐----------------------------------------------------- Highlight the skills and experience that are most relevant to the job. Here are some additional tips: * Use action verbs to describe your accomplishments. * Quantify your accomplishments whenever possible. * Keep your resume concise and easy to read. * Use a professional font and layout. -----------------------------------‐---------------------------------- …more

Use These copy-and-paste AI Prompts to Craft a Standout Cover Letter 👇  Make a lasting impression. Get more interviews. Land your dream role!  Try these 7 prompts to supercharge your cover letter:  ✉️ Prompt 1: Personalized Opening Creator Draft an engaging introduction tailored to [Company Name]. Highlight recent initiatives, values, or achievements. Create three variations: one focused on cultural alignment, one on innovation, and one on solving key challenges. 🚀 Resume Tips to Stand Out! Your resume isn’t just a document—it’s your personal brand. Make it impactful with these key tips: 1️⃣ Show, Don’t Tell – Instead of claiming you're skilled, prove it through concrete achievements and real-world results. 2️⃣ Skip Overused Buzzwords – Hardworking and team player are filler words. Let your accomplishments speak for themselves. 3️⃣ Showcase Your Career Growth – Highlight promotions to demonstrate your progress and recognition in previous roles. 4️⃣ Put Your Best Work First – Arrange your resume so that your strongest projects and achievements are at the top. 5️⃣ Use Bold Text – Highlight the technologies you used and the impact of your work to make key details stand out. 6️⃣ Keep It Concise – Remove redundancy and keep your resume clear, structured, and to the point. 7️⃣ Maintain a Clean, Professional Look – Skip the photo and fancy designs. A simple black-and-white layout ensures readability and professionalism. 8️⃣ Be Specific, Not Generic – Phrases like "developed multiple APIs" or "fixed several bugs" lack impact. It seems like the purpose of a resume has shifted over the years. What used to be a representation of what I have done has now turned into a mirror of what a job posting says. Why is that?  Resumes are supposed to tell the story of my career — the skills I’ve developed, the challenges I’ve overcome, the value I bring to the table. Yet now, it feels like they are being molded to fit specific keywords and criteria, which often doesn't even capture the full picture of my expertise.  As someone who's looking to transition into a new career field, I’m also facing the challenge of how to reframe my experience. How do we balance staying true to our professional journeys while also satisfying algorithm-driven filters?  What do you think, and community? How do we reclaim the authenticity of our resumes while also ensuring they are seen — especially when making a career transition?  …more

The most common resume mistake I see when working with people:  Including a measurable result  ... that you literally can't measure.  ChatGPT does a great job pulling measurable results to put in your resume when you type in this prompt:  "What are some measurable accomplishments JOB POSITION can put in their resume?"  But it'll give you ideas that are clearly ChatGPT'd.  "Improved time from order to serving food by 25%"  Did you really time every order and calculate how much your "tailored customer service strategy reduced xyz"?  ...and was it really exactly a 25% increase?  Make sure you pick results that are measurable & more importantly TRUE  You can fully expect the interviewer to press you on "how exactly did you achieve this result?" Jeff Nevez, here with APC! I've seen countless resumes pass my desk. Unfortunately, some don’t make it to the next step for common, avoidable reasons. Here's what might be holding yours back:  🔑 Lack of Relevant Experience If your experience doesn't align with the job, recruiters may move on. Tailor your resume to highlight the most relevant skills and achievements.  📝 Poor Resume Formatting A cluttered or difficult-to-read resume can be a dealbreaker. Stick to a clean format with clear headings and bullet points.  📚 Missing Keywords Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) scan for specific keywords. If they’re missing, your resume may be filtered out before anyone sees it.  ⏳ Employment Gaps Without Explanation Gaps happen, and that’s okay—but explain them. Highlight growth during these periods, whether through learning, caregiving, or volunteering.  🎯 Generic Objective Statements Outdated or vague objectives don’t help. Use a strong professional summary to show your value upfront.  🔍 Typos and Grammar Errors Mistakes show a lack of attention to detail. Double-check or ask someone to review it for you.  ⚠️ Inconsistent or Inaccurate Information Inconsistent job titles or inflated claims raise red flags. Honesty is key.  📊 Lack of Measurable Achievements Just listing job duties isn’t enough. Show your impact using numbers, percentages, and results.  💡 By addressing these points, you’ll significantly increase your chances of getting noticed. Want more resume tips or career advice? 💡 Tips for Crafting a Winning Resume! 🚀  Your resume is your personal marketing tool. It needs to capture attention and showcase your skills and experience in the best light possible. Here are some essential tips to make your resume stand out:  1. Clear Contact Information Make sure your name, phone number, email address, and LinkedIn profile are easy to find. If you have a personal website or portfolio, include that too!  2. Compelling Professional Summary Kick things off with a brief but powerful summary of your experience, strengths, and career goals. This sets the tone for the rest of your resume.  3. Tailored Skills Section List relevant skills for the job you're applying for. Focus on a balance of both hard and soft skills that match the role.  4. Achievements Over Responsibilities Instead of just listing job duties, highlight your key achievements. Quantify your successes with numbers (e.g., increased sales by 30%, led a team of 5).  5. Experience That Shows Impact Describe your roles using action verbs and focus on the impact you made. This will demonstrate your contribution and value to potential employers.  6. Keep It Concise A resume should be no longer than 1-2 pages. Be concise and cut out unnecessary information. Employers often skim resumes, so make it easy for them to spot key details.  7. Education & Certifications List your degrees, certifications, and any additional training relevant to the job. Be sure to include dates and institutions.  8. Use Keywords Many companies use Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) to scan resumes. Include keywords from the job description to ensure your resume gets noticed.  9. Formatting Is Key Keep your resume clean, professional, and easy to read. Use bullet points, bold for headings, and leave enough white space to make it visually appealing.  10. Proofread, Proofread, Proofread! Typos can make a bad impression! Always proofread your resume (or ask a friend) to catch any errors.  Remember, your resume is often the first impression a recruiter or hiring manager gets of you, make it count! 🌟    …more

Your resume gets 6 seconds.   SIX SECONDS. That’s all recruiters need...  To decide if your CV lands in the “no thanks” pile.  If your resume is sending the wrong signals, it’s game over—before you’ve even started.  Here’s how to fix it fast:  1. "I Didn’t Read the Job Posting." 🔴 Red Flag: Clichés like “detail-oriented” or “team player.” 🟢 Fix It: Mirror the job description. Use keywords and highlight specific achievements.  2. "I’m Living in the Past." 🔴 Red Flag: Listing ancient or irrelevant experience. 🟢 Fix It: Focus on the last 10 years. Keep it lean & relevant.  3. "I’m Afraid of Technology." 🔴 Red Flag: No mention of tools or platforms. 🟢 Fix It: Add your tech stack—Excel, Salesforce, or certifications. Digital fluency is mandatory.  4. "I’m Hiding Something." 🔴 Red Flag: Unexplained employment gaps. 🟢 Fix It: Fill the gaps—showcase freelancing, volunteering, or upskilling. Control the narrative.  5. "I Don’t Sweat the Details." 🔴 Red Flag: Typos, inconsistent formatting, outdated info. 🟢 Fix It: Use Grammarly. Polished resumes show you care.  6. "I Have No Results to Show." 🔴 Red Flag: Vague phrases like “managed a team” or “responsible for projects.” 🟢 Fix It: Quantify everything: “Boosted sales by 25%” > “Managed a team.”  7. "I’m Just Sending This Everywhere." 🔴 Red Flag: Generic resumes sent to every job. 🟢 Fix It: Highlight wins that match the job description.  8. "I’m Desperate." 🔴 Red Flag: Applying for every job under the sun. 🟢 Fix It: Stay focused. Align your resume to roles that tell one clear story.  🔥 Your Resume = Your Pitch.  If it’s not selling your story, it’s time for a rewrite.  What is your resume really saying about you?  ♻️ Share this to help someone today! 🔔 And followfor more. …more

Most résumés are boring and forgettable.  Here’s how to make yours stand out.   Most people treat their résumé like a history book, listing every job they’ve had and every task they’ve done.   But hiring managers don’t need a timeline, they need a reason to say YES.  Here’s how to make your résumé stand out in a way most people overlook:  🔹 Write for the Future, Not the Past Your résumé should position you for the job you WANT, not just reflect what you’ve done. Tailor your skills and accomplishments to align with the next step in your career.  🔹 Your Job Title Isn’t Enough, Show the Impact Instead of “Managed training programs,” say “Designed and implemented training programs that increased employee productivity by 30%.” Numbers tell a story.  🔹 Your Summary Shouldn’t Be Boring Avoid clichés like “hardworking professional seeking opportunities.” Instead, answer: What makes you different? Why should they hire YOU?  🔹 Remove Fluff That Wastes Space Phrases like “responsible for” or “assisted with” weaken your impact. Get straight to the result. What did you do? What happened because of it?  🔹 Make It Easy to Skim Hiring managers scan résumés in seconds. Use bold headings, bullet points, and clear formatting so they can see your value fast.  Your résumé isn’t just a document, it’s your first impression.  Make them want to know more.  Does your résumé sell your value or just list your past?  …more

👀 Is Your Resume Easy to Read?  After you’ve created your resume, take a moment to visually inspect it. Why? Because if it’s hard to read or navigate, it might not get the attention it deserves. Here’s a quick checklist to ensure it stands out: 🔍 Top-to-Bottom Flow Does your resume naturally guide the reader’s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? That’s the most critical part—if it’s hard to find, you’re doing yourself a disservice.  📂 Key Details at a Glance Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.  🎯 Communicating Accomplishments Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments you’d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.  💡 Pro Tip If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. It's one of the most common questions hiring managers have when reviewing a resume. "What's that company do?"  …more

𝐂𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬: Keep it clear and to the point. Use bullet points to break down your achievements and make them easy to read.   3. 𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐒𝐩𝐞𝐚𝐤 𝐋𝐨𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐫: Quantify your achievements. 💥 Day 96 of  hashtag #100ResumeTips: Share value fast!  Imagine for a moment that you need assistance with a pain point. Let's say your requirement is a plumbing issue in your home. You go to the bookstore seeking a book on basic plumbing. When you arrive at the bookstore, hundreds of books are in the plumbing section.  You start picking books off the shelf and giving them a quick scan.  During the scan, if a book doesn't immediately catch your eye and address your needs - the chances are high that you will move on to the next one.  Your resume is no different. It may only get a quick scan. If it does not immediately address the reader's needs and provide value fast - it may get passed over. …more

Top 5 resume tips that get you interviews:  1. Lead with the section of your resume with the most value.  Example: if you don't have any experience but have a Masters in Business Analytics, start your resume with your education section.  2. Show specific, numeric impact.  Example: Increased gross revenue by 3% as measure by...  ❌ don't use generic or fake percentages like 20% or 50%. If you cant measure impact, don't use a percentage.  3. Only include skills that you can validate.  Example: If you include Machine Learning in your skills section, you better have some machine learning project or experience in your resume.  4. Add the title you want to be on your resume.  Example: if you have done data analytics at a previous job, but you worked in operations, ask your previous manager if you can change the job title to data analyst on your linkedin and resume.  5. Use 𝗯𝗼𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 strategically.  ❌ don't bold skills ✅ bold your impact or outcome of a project  what important resume tips am I missing?  …more
